description:
Ah... Washington Bakery... been going here for over a decade or two. I think they are great and I try to come here every chance I get. You can't miss it if you parked in the parking structure under the park. When you come out of the elevators, go up the hill on Washington and it's the first restaurant on the left. Their food a very authentic and their services has gotten much better! 

There has not been anything here that I have ordered that I didn't like. They have breakfast menu from 7:30-11am, with breakfast price ($6) and breakfast size. Breakfast comes with a coffee or tea. They are best known for their congee or porridge; five different kind to choose from and it comes with fried bread, which is awesome! If you are adventurous, I highly recommend the pork giblet or the 1000 year preserved egg with pork porridge. 

Their wonton soups, chow mien, chow fun or fried rice are bomb. Someday, I will need to come and try them for dinner. 

Everyone raves and stand in long line for the GG Bakery but I think this place is just as good and you don't have to wait in a long line. 

Milk tea with boba... I always take one to go!
author: Tinah Y.

description:
Had 2 take out orders and one was a plain wonton.  My mom was taking the last bite of her wonton and she bit on something hard, turned out to be something that looked like a rock.  Called the restaurant to let them know and all they can say is oh thanks.  

Overrated!!
author: Wayne W.

description:
Overpriced with average food 

The kids wanted to come here so I said.... why not 
My mistake. The place is pretty terrible. My baby cousin was disgusted by the food and plates. The plates came out wet with food still on the utensils. My other cousins came here a year ago and ordered what they ordered last time because they liked it. The food came out different. We asked for plain shrimp wontons. They had mushrooms in it. 
The fried rice is so plain we had to add soy sauce to it. 
House special noodles was just birds nest noodles. 
$55 later.... for 4 items
author: Emily L.

description:
TL;DR good place for HK style food

Washington Cafe is a great place to go if you're a fan of HK style restaurants. A combination of Chinese and American food. My two friends and I shared beef, chicken, and wonton noodles. My favorite was the wonton noodle bc the other two dishes were pretty oily. Their portions are huge so I'd recommend sharing. We barely ate half of our food. They have a large menu, so you have a lot to choose from!
author: Sophia L.

description:
This is still a yummy place!

We got the beef with vegetables over rice, seafood pan fried noodles, and sweet and sour chicken. We practically devoured all the things. :P

Prices have gone up since the last time I wrote a review ($8 to now...$11 to $12 per dish). The seafood pan-fried noodle was maybe my favorite. The noodles were crunchy and deliciously soft once the sauce softened them up. Everything came out at a good speed despite it being really busy. 

We had really good service too.
author: Natalie M.

description:
Washington Bakery & Restaurant is part bakery (in the front) and part Hong Kong Style Cafe on Washington Street in the heart of Chinatown in SF. I've passed by it many times but have not tried it as it seems to be a bit too touristy for my liking. A couple of days ago I decided to give it a try nonetheless. I stepped inside and walked over to the ordering station only to be completely ignored by the server who was closing out the check for someone else. When I tried to engage, she handed me off to another older and more experienced server who spoke perfect English and was very courteous. It seems they have a system here to let the more experienced servers deal with "tourists" who happen to walk in.

Anyway let's come to the menu. It is your standard Cantonese menu with gazillion choices from wonton noodle soup, porridge, rice plates, pan fried noodles to curries and snacks. As it claims to be a Hong Kong Style Café I decided to get the Hong Kong specialty of baked rice and went with the baked seafood with satay sauce with spaghetti ($10.50).  After ordering I was pleasantly surprised as I was able to pay by card. After ordering it was almost a 15 minute wait sitting on one of the empty table out front and I was on my way.

A got a large container that was lined with a silver foil that contained the baked seafood over spaghetti. The first thing I noticed was how runny the baked seafood was. First bite confirmed that this had way too much satay sauce and had not spent enough time in the oven to have been baked correctly. It was sufficiently loaded but had tiny shrimps. I would have preferred it they would have given a less number of decent sized shrimp. Overall it seemed like I was eating regular seafood noodles with satay sauce.

Price wise it was about 15% more expensive than VIP Coffee & Cake shop and Café Honolulu with its food sitting in the middle of the two with VIP on top and Honolulu on the bottom. Looking at the complete package of quality, service and value for money I'd say Washington Bakery & Restaurant is A-Ok.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
1. The ac is nice and strong in the morning
2. The servers are fast 
3. Only Chinese people here but are bilingual
4. Food is cheap in the morning 
5. Can't beat a 6.00 breakfast
6. I come here all the time when I'm in San Francisco
author: Bruce S.

description: This is such an awesome, authentic HK style restaurant. I always come for their milk tea and have eaten here like over 100 times over a 10 years period. The waitress are still the same and know me by name. I love their baked seafood rice or the baked two meat piece rice. You can choose spaghetti noodles on white or red sauce. It takes about 15 min to get the stuff baked. Plus it is worth the wait with the extra melted cheese. $.25-.50 for the extra. Everything gets charged but I gladly support the businesses in Chinatown as I don't want them to go out of business. The varieties of items range from traditional Chinese to cafe style to western flavors. I like the fact these they are not heavy on MSG and they taste good without mixing heavy sauces on top. Please don't count on any services here, really, this is China town not your fairmount or Palace hotel. Their pastry are all good, decent enough to take to company meetings. I always go with the coffee roll cakes or the "old wife" cake. It is white and chewy with the chestnut in the fillings. The morning breakfasts are $6 with bacon/sausage and egg. Marconi soup or Chinese traditional breakfast of thin noodles with shrimp/beef or other assortment of congees. Both come with a small plate of fried "oily pieces" (it is fried floured bread that is light and tasty, not too sweet or Salty" that's it for now.
author: Connie L.

description:
Chinatown, my Chinatown
Almond eyes of brown
Hearts are light and lights are bright
In dreamy Chinatown

Yes, the lights are very bright in here, but almond eyes of brown? Jeez, what a racist comment back in the day when they wrote this old chestnut of a song. I certainly don't like my eyes compared to something you find in a tin of Planter's mixed nuts, but we Asians are used to suffering. We even get dragged out of overbooked United flights even when it's not our fault. But I digress as Jamie W. and I were looking for something sweet after a hearty meal of pork chow fun and sesame chicken at Sam Wo's. We usually find ourselves at the Eastern Bakery for a slice of coffee crunch cake, but I felt a need for something different. We came upon a sea of green formica under bright, flickering florescent lights (photo: http://bit.ly/2p67EOh).

Too bad I forgot to bring my sunglasses. We took a look at the dessert display case and decided to try a trio of their sweets, in fact, almost the last three kinds they had for sale. There was a Custard Puff and a Cream Puff shaped like a swan, both for $1.50 (photo: http://bit.ly/2oiD5QM). They called them Buffs, but they apparently didn't use spell check. Bland and a little hard given how long they were probably in a refrigerated state. Marginally better was the $3 slice of Mocha Chestnut Cake Roll, still refrigerated in texture but at least it had more of a discernible flavor with the almond slices on top (photo: http://bit.ly/2p6b6Zv). They also serve hot food, but I'll remember to apply sunscreen before returning.

FOOD - 2 stars...oddly bland and heavily refrigerated
AMBIANCE - 2 stars...interrogation rooms have more warmth
SERVICE - 1.5 stars...very prickly
TOTAL - 2 stars...did I mention I have almond eyes of brown?
author: Ed U.

description: Ordered a braised noodle with eggplant. Looked and tasted gross. I think they made the dish two days ago & refried it. A lot of Chinese people were eating here when we walked in but would not recommend, I couldn't eat the food. The drinks looked good though.
author: Michelle H.

description:
This place ain't the best. Their service is between mediocre to terrible. Their food is decent but there aren't many old chinese restaurants/cafes in Chinatown anymore so I come here. I like their wonton noodle soup though. 

If you ignore the ladies barking at you when you order and having to win them over just so they will hear you out when they messed up your order, this place is tolerable. Oh, if you order to go on the phone, be prepared for mean/rude ladies but just keep your eyes on the prize, you'll get to eat soon!
author: Betty L.

description: A little place in Chinatown, Washington Bakery & Restaurant is baking and cooking some good Chinese cuisine. I didn't get to try their cooking skills, but I did get a bit of Chinese baked goods. Plus, they make fresh drinks here as well. I was a bit full when I stopped here with a pal, but I did get a cream based bun with a lychee drink. The lychee drink was sooooo fresh! It was like they literally went into the back and picked them off the tree and blended them. I really appreciated that fresh taste from my drink. I love pastries and I have had a few too many in my life to tell the difference from a good one and a bad one. The bun I got was really light like a fresh croissant and the cream was smooth. It was a nice bite to eat after the food I consumed earlier that day. Overall, I had a nice and pleasant stop at this establishment. Plus, Bill Clinton has been here! So, it was definitely a must to go in here.
author: Tarita T.

description:
Wow! I've lived in Germany where cakes are not sweet. But this cake is a step above all cakes I've had. I love cakes!!! We celebrated my sons 5 birthday and I had to buy a generic cake. The flavor was by all means not generic. The taste and freshness of the fruit was fresh and creamy. The frosting was not butter cream but whipped cream (my favorite). This cake would be great with coffee. 

If we lived closer I'd frequent this place more often. This will be my go to cake place if we are in the SF area.
author: Dorothy B.

description:
The service was excellent! Our waitress was very sweet and she made sure we were taken care of. I honestly never experienced this in a Chinese restaurant before. It was about closing time, but she let us know that we can take our time eating. She also asked if we needed to use the restroom before they closed up. And as they were moping the floor, she told us to watch our step. How frikin' nice is that?! We made sure to tip her well!

Now onto the food. The pan fried noodles was delicious and exactly what I was expecting. We also had the salt and pepper wings and won ton noodle soup. Honestly everything was pretty solid and we were more than content with our meal and experience. 

Definitely will be back next time I'm in Chinatown!
author: Amanda T.

description:
This place was pretty pricy all things considering for it's location in Chinatown. Although I really enjoyed the porridge, the vegetables was very uninspiring. We got two different vegetable dishes and they actually tasted pretty much like the same dish but with two different vegetables. The texture of the meats in the vegetable dishes was not good either. It was very chewy and didn't taste like it was cooked properly.

There's plenty of much better china town restaurants. Don't come to this one unless you're desperate.
author: Cassie Z.

description:
Update:  while visiting the Great Star theater, my friends said to go here. I remember the food was good and desserts yummy. 

As I perused the color menu; something grabbed my eye: quack, quack!
I ordered the roast duck/wonton soup; choice of noodles: egg or rice. I chose egg noodles.

After a brief time, my soup arrived, it's a good sized bowl of soup.

The scent and look was good. The broth tasty and not too salty. The egg noodles had a nice texture and were slightly chewy. Perfect! It was packed with won ton's and plump roast duck; replete with all the juicy, yummy texture only roast duck can provide. $9.00 for this much goodness, is nice.

Tip: two light eaters could enjoy this big bowl of soup.

Parking: street, but's it's better to park at a local public parking garage.
author: Bert K.

description: Has good selection of dimsum items on display for takeout. Also can order food (dine-in). Good location and walking distance from hotels and Portsmouth Square Park. Clean establishment
author: A L.

description:
Service was terrible, they toss your spoons and chop sticks at your table.... Never came to give you the bill or refill water... No wonder this place was basically empty when I came. 

Plus the server keeps talking to you in another language... if a customer is speaking to you in English they OBVIOusLY don't know what you are saying!

Go to another place in chinatown there are plenty! follow the crowd and skip this establishment.....
author: Cameron L.

description: Found no problems with the restaurant at all. Bill Clinton once ate here. The food was extremely delicious and served piping hot. The waitress recommended a tasty dish and it was great. Go with your instinct... you will be surprised. The portions are huge... enough for 2 people and left overs to take back to your hotel.
author: Becky G.

description:
bad. this place is mediocre at best. food is so overpriced.
portions are soooo small. 
food is bad. 
bathrooma are disgusting. 
extra charges on dumb stuff like iced drinks. 

don't come.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Great Hongkong food with unbeatable price! Came along for dinner and ordered a beef stew wanton noodle soup. Added some veggies to the noodles. Also got a yuanyang milk tea. 

What's great about it:
1) best value for what you pay for! So many peaces of beef stew, a pile of vegetables, wontons were filled with shrimps and a lot of rice noodle at the bottom. 

2) the taste of the dish was well balanced. Beef and wonton were on the salty side, balanced with veggies and noodles which are bland. The soup has a gorgeous taste that paired well was the food.

Things that are good to know:
1) the hot drink has a pretty small portion
2) the glass noodle became really soggy after a while. I think that's because they over cooked it
3) the decoration of the restaurant was pretty simple--more for casual eating!
author: Yujie F.

description:
I went here for a $3 milk tea. The employee selling it to me wasn't all that. It's partly because I spoke English instead of Cantonese, but mostly because she didn't like my look, regardless of shared ethnicity. 

I sat quietly at one of the tables in the back, enjoying my tea. Then a lady came and rudely said I couldn't sit there. She said it was just for "table service." She originally spoke to me in Cantonese, but quickly switched to English because of the "look" on my face. (I'm a Mandarin speaker.) She claimed it was just for "table service," and told me to bring my drink outside. 

I know of no such policy. But of course, like all things, it's YMMV. My mileage is always at -1000% because they think I look ugly. It doesn't matter how kind, genuine, polite, and well-dressed I am - I will always get exceptionally poor and unfair service. 

There were lots of tables available, so there was no reason to kick me out. Ugly people get treated much worse, and much more unfairly, all things being equal. And it's not even all things being equal - do/wear/say something much better, and you'll still be treated much worse and unfairly. 

Next time, you try sitting there with a drink and not ordering "table service." Guaranteed that same lady will let you sit there, without kicking you out - especially if you're white and pretty.
author: Valle H.

description:
You come here for a quick HK cafe style meal, not for ambience, service, or really food quality. 

Stopped in here cause it took credit card and I was short on cash. I ordered the shrimp and egg over noodles (fun) and my coworkers got the baked pork chop over rice and Hainan chicken over rice. They seemed to like their food okay. The portions are huge, the prices are cheap, but the food was just okay. Good enough when you're just looking for food to fill the tummy.
author: Maggie Y.

description:
We went there for lunch on a weekday and ordered two set lunch. 
i. Fish fillet noodles 
ii. Hainan Chicken Rice

The Fish fillet noodles arrived for almost 20 mins before the Hainan Chicken rice arrives. We did asked the staff for our Hainan chicken rice twice and we just saw multiple Hainan Chicken rices were served to customers who came in AFTER us. 

At the end, we were offered additional a small plate of vegetables and a bowl of WHITE RICE. For those who understand the beauty of Hainan chicken rice is the match between the chicken and the OILY rice. 

Price:
Decent for what you paid for.
author: Chin Man L.

description: The coffee was watery, diluted at best. The noodles for the wonton soup and the beef tasted like it didn't have a proper water bath and bleached.  I won't recommend them. The pastries looked good and a pro was that the waiters were friendly and accommodating.
author: Shannon W.

description:
CHEAP!
Nice service!
Good food!
I ordered:
Cod with BBS HK style noodle and Black Pepper Beef with chow fun!
Amazing.
Clean too.
author: Candice L.

description: Nope. This place used to be a whole lot better in the past. Portion sizes are smaller for the noodle soups but the prices are a lot higher. I was still hungry after I finished my meal.
author: W A.

description: I've frequented and referred this place numerous times to the point where it's an ace in the hole.  Even during midweek lunch hour, they're fast, friendly & an extensive menu.
author: Jim I.

description:
Yum! This review is for the bakery part of the restaurant. They have a great selection of sweet and savory buns. I got the following:

-pineapple bun
-taro bun
-curry beef bun
-pork floss bun
-ham and cheese bun


From the filling to the actual bread itself, I thought it was perfect and had the right flavors and textures. Not to mention, it was super cheap at $1.25-1.50/bun!
author: Stephanie B.

description: This was one of our favorites in SFO Chinatown but was quite disappointed this time.  Egg noodles were okay, wontons were not good and vermicelli noodles tasted and looked like they came out of a ramen package.  Besides Hong Kong style teas & coffee don't think we will be going back.
author: Linda C.

description: YUCK! Poor food safety at Washington Bakery And Cafe. Ordered my morning cup of joe to find that the waitress used an old cup. I saw a newbie waitress ordered by her supervisor to use old cup that had been sitting on the counter for God knows how long. It had spoon in it with all the stains of a used cup. I confronted the newbie waitress and was given the shrug that the milk tea was newly made. What about the old cup???!!!! This place just lost a customer.
author: SF F.

description: It's not great the Thai tea looks like poop and tastes as bad as it looks. We sat down to eat our food that we brought while we drank our shitty Thai tea and the lady stared at us for 10 minutes and as we were almost done eating she had the decency to yell at us in her half English half mandarin high pitched voice. Definitely will not go back there ever again. I'd give it no stars if I could
author: Angus R.

description:
Like the Hong Kong styled milk tea a lot, which is robust, creamy and authentic.

The services were pretty fast and down-to-earth.

Today I ordered Hainan chicken with rice.  The rice was tasty with the aroma of the chicken.  The chicken itself was off standard.  The chicken skin was not crispy as it should be.  The chicken had a weird smell that is never part of Hainan chicken.

It's also annoying to see an inset flying around today.

It is ok to have a quick bite or to get a snack here, but not necessary to treat friends/family.
author: Flora Z.

description: First time here. I had a wonton soup. So disappointed how small the portion was. The egg crate was so watery with no favor. The broth was OK. Tea served in a metal root beer cup. Really!? Not coming back to this place. Plus, Bill "I didn't inhale" or "Had intercourse" Clinton are here. Definitely not coming back here.
author: Ke L.

description: I've eaten at this restaurant a couple of times with my parents. We ate here today. We had chicken(see pic), shrimp and fried egg noodles, and a large pot of wonton. It was a nice meal. I like visiting Chinatown and eating at restaurants like this. I also had a milk tea with tapioca. A simply good traditional Chinese meal and also Happy Chinese New Year!
author: Denise C.

description:
what i ordered... mongolian beef with rice

Mongolian beef is good and typical... just enough beef with lots of onion and green onions

ambiance... so-so (spacious but cluttered)
service... bad (stoic)
cost... $ (fair)
author: Gors P.

description: We have 17 people and were waiting for 45 minuets but only got two soup noodles, two vegetable dishes. The most shock thing was we saw a big rat running through the restaurant. NEVER come again!!!
author: Linda L.

description:
First time in my life that a HK style cafe combo doesn't come with milk tea.  Milk tea with a dish is traditional HK style.

Watch the small print people.  The combo comes with coffee and couple drinks etc... but not milk tea.

Officially the restaurant wanna trick you and charge extra for the milk tea.  

It's not Starbucks for Christ sake.  $3 on top for a milk tea.
author: Alex T.

description:
I was a bit homesick Cantonese cuisine, and went into this place. Certain things, and certain flavors can be resurrected. But, the quality here; it's just horrible. It is Cantonese cuisine, but way too greasy. 

Noodles were doughy and sticky.

I also don't like how the cashier insists on having a tip when there was almost NO SERVICE.
author: Mike K.

description: Where to even start? The service was completely rude and terrible. The waitress kept leaving the table when we were in the middle of ordering and she slammed plates down on the table. When paying, she kept looking at our bill to see how much we were going tip. Once we tipped, she had the nerve to say the tip I left wasn't good enough and for me to change the amount to something higher. She didn't even give us a re-fill on our water when we asked. The bathrooms were really dirty as well and you can hear the staff waiting by the door, yelling so loud as well. Made it a really uncomfortable experience. Definitely not coming back here.
author: Siera O.

description:
Literally the worst customer service restaurant in town. The waitress and owner pretend don't see you at all and will not TAKE THE ORDERS!!! We waited for 10-15 minutes and no one serves us, I guess they just DON'T LIKE "foreigners"!!! If you don't like your job, just quit it. No one force you to do it. That old waitress is the worst, she looked you and just pretend not seeing you. Worst experience, no any respect for the people who work in here. Disgusting!!! Should feel shame of yourself...

PS we just walked out the restaurant just like that, won't do the business with the people who won't respect the others.
author: Frances H.

description: Food is good and cheap. I really like The Hong Kong milk tea.
author: Ann Y.

description:
Good food. Appetizer: hot pork buns. Now that was good. Ordered hot pepper beef chow
Mein which was delicious & hot pot chicken served with onions. Delicious! 

Also, ordered a lemon honey ice tea. Super sweet with lemon slices inside.

Cleanliness: unsure what the grade is? Restroom is questionable.  

That's all
author: Rose B.

description:
Great place for some jook  (Chinese rice porridge) on a cold rainy morning.


Pretty  clean as Chinese restaurants go.  Everything is yummy and cooked to order.


The Chinese donuts are crispy and sooooo bad for you, but too good to skip adding to the porridge.
author: Jerry W.

description:
I passed by this restaurant couple times before, finally had a chance to try it out; and I have to say that I haven't had a chance to use the phrase "extremely disappointed" in a while to describe Chinese dishes that I eat.

Came here on a Saturday around 1pm; the restaurant was only about half full. The environment is considered fairly clean and tidy compared to average Chinatown restaurants. Thought it was a good start.

-) Steamed Shrimp Rice Roll (蒸蝦腸): B-. The rice roll was made very thick. If you do a cross section I would say the rice roll itself consumed 90% of the thickness. And the shrimp was not only small in size but also there were only very few of them. Shrimp was obviously not fresh at all.

-) Baked White Sauce Seafood Rice: C. You can see from the picture I took, this baked rice dish was extremely watery. I almost wanted to ask whether they have done cooking it or not. Couple of reasons could lead to this: 1. Amount of cheese they put was at a minimum. 2. Scallop - which needs special handling because it holds a lot of water in the body, should be fully dried before cooking it. I'm pretty sure they did not do that. Shrimp was again small and tasteless. The rice was just covered with water. 

-) Iced Milk Tea: B-. Watery, not so much taste in it.

A very unsatisfied meal. I don't think I will come back again.
author: Simon C.

description:
4 stars for the food. But 2 stars for the after effects. The menu is typical of a Hong Kong diner - a mixture of Eastern and Western.

Atmosphere:

Washington Bakery & Restaurant is the epitome of a dingy Cantonese restaurant in Chinatown. With extremely low standards of decor and probably cleanliness, this place should've been questionable from the start.

Customer Service:

The typical Chinese no-nonsense attitude of service but nothing spectacular in other areas such as efficiency either.

Food:

Here's where I'm torn. We ordered a Portuguese Chicken Rice Bake along with Beef Ho Fun. Both dishes are absolutely delicious and packed full of flavour. I was pretty addicted to the Portuguese Chicken Rice Bake and couldn't get enough!

Unfortunately, later in the day I developed a pretty awful stomach ache and had food poisoning (was the only thing I've eaten so far so it couldn't have been anything else). A damn shame, because the food was delicious and would've easily gotten a 4 stars from me.

Additionally, considering how there are other reviewers who have also experienced health issues following visits to Washington Bakery, I would probably avoid coming back.
author: Clarissa Y.

description:
Oh my god, I thought I would never find this restaurant on Yelp as my brother did everything in his power to try to get me to magically forget this place. When I was in San Francisco, this is the first place my brother brought my parents and I to eat. Let me say it was absolutely disgusting. The first thing I saw when inside were roaches and with all the available seating they had to put us in the most crammed space right next to other people.

We ordered the
Pork Chop Rice Lunch Special
Chicken Fried Rice Lunch Special
Bitter Melon w/Beef Rice Lunch Special
Chinese Brocolli

The lunch special was $5 and comes with your choice of Tea, Coffee or Soy Milk. Let me start off by saying the fried rice was anything but fried. It could pass for mixed rice or wet casserole but NOT Fried. The Pork Chops were really off, tasting more like mushed soggy meat. I mean for all I know, it was more like a discarded food from other customers but reheated by boiling. 

Enough said. When I wanted another small cup of Soy Milk, they charged $3. If I knew that I could have got another lunch special....well maybe not. The only reason I would come back is not to eat but because how they put the rice on the plate is actually very amusing. ;-)
author: Alex H.

description: Went there for lunch, I really like the to miau, shrimp walnut, chicken and salty fish fried rice, char kuetiaw with beef, Hainam chicken with haiman rice and some other stuff I don't remember. We also ordered avocado and taro bobas, wasn't good. At least the waitress speak English. Restroom wasn't clean as expected.
author: Royeni T.

description: They gave me a good amount of food, however, it was too oily for me. Average service and not too busy during lunch hours.
author: Bertina Z.

description: Visited here for the 1st time yesterday after researching reviews and decided to order the wonton noodles, baked pork chop over rice, and the vermicelli noodles. It was seriously the best authentic Chinese meal we've had in a while, at least in the US! It tasted authentic to Hong Kong style and I'm already wanting to go back again before we leave SF. The wonton noodles were so flavorful and so was the baked pork chop over rice. The vermicelli noodles lacked a bit of flavor but all in all, it was still good. Def going to go back and try some other dishes. Highly recommend this place if you want to have authentic Cantonese style dishes!
author: Karen K.

description: Visiting San Francisco sms meeting with colleagues. Good food. Large portions. Reasonable prices. Huge selection. We have a 1 year old and they brought a high chair right away and were very accommodating and friendly.
author: Wolf M.

description:
Walked in the restroom to wash my hands and didn't have soap.  Checked the ladies room and it didn't have soap either!   Makes you wonder how they're keeping your plates and food sanitary.

I wish I'd checked the other times I've been here ordering take-out
author: Drew B.

description:
This is my go-to place to eat in ChinaTown. 

*Food: I got the Wednesday Special = Curry Chicken Rice Plate
 This Chinese Curry is odd. I like it but it is different than other curries I have had before. This curry is more yellow and slimy. It is not as flavorful BUT if you add a little bit of that Chinese Red Chili Sauce, the taste is so much BETTER. The chicken though, it is good. The chicken is soft and I like it! There are potato and onion slices and the potato is really good. It does not just taste boiled or steam but it was marinated. 

*Service: The lady that served us was RUDE. It felt like she was hating her job. lol She was like "What do you want? What? You want what?" lol. Rude lady. 
BTW....I ordered a glass of soy milk and the cup was DIRTY. There was previous drink stains and it was NOT pleasant.
author: Katie P.

description: This has got to be the worst restaurant I've ever eaten at.  Plates and utensils were given to us wet and dirty. They gave us the wrong orders. And the food we ate was pretty gross. I bought a piece of bread at the front of the restaurant for my son to eat since he would not open his mouth to eat a single thing I ordered and the lady microwaved it for at least a minute, so the bread was scorching hot when I got it. I didn't ask her to heat it up. At least heat it up enough so the customer can eat it without having to wait 5 minutes for it to cool down. Anyway, I will never come back again, the food was disgusting and the place is sooo dirty.
author: Gloria S.

description:
Came by for a iced milk tea the other day and it was okay. Requested less sugar and it came out good. Requested an iced beverage and the room-temperature tea came out with a little bit of crushed ice on top...

At $3.25, pricing was slightly pricey
author: Derek S.

description:
The waitresses may not be the friendliest or understand a lick of English, but this Hong Kong style restaurant makes some pretty good dishes. For a fact, this may be one of the better ones in Chinatown. 

I was here a few weeks ago for lunch, I had the Rock cod and creamed corn over rice. For $7.50, the customary rice plate had eight chunky pieces of battered fish meat in a creamy corn sauce over white rice. Some places are stingy and will give you 4-5 small pieces of the seafood. But here, you will get twice as much. And the price isn't bad either. My first meal:  http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/washington-bakery-and-restaurant-san-francisco?select=pjdzNnoNtFV4DeO5ZYdA5g#RWaLNA54PDx3PVdLRZPMFA

On my second trip back, I was here for my early dinner before heading to the Warrior's game at Oracle Arena. "I am not paying $10.00 for a lousy hot dog at the arena!" I had the dried beef chow fun. For $7.00, the dish was steeper than most (still cheaper and better than food from any sport venues), but the pasta dish came out quick and piping hot. The wide pasta and meat was not too burnt.  I also added a glass of creamy Hong Kong-style iced tea for $3.50. "Yes, I am drinking tea, folks...so quit shaking your cranium! My second meal: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/washington-bakery-and-restaurant-san-francisco?select=pjdzNnoNtFV4DeO5ZYdA5g#SJR8pNCCt49R_cuRb409WQ

There is also a Chinese-style bakery here too. So don't forget to grab a sweet (or two) after your meal; "One custard tart, please!"
author: Matt G.

description:
First time here!  My bf discovered this place with his friend recently so we decided to go for lunch today.  I just got out of the gym so I was ready to eat!  I got the shrimp dumpling noodles and he got the kung pao chicken.  Loved the shrimp dumpling noodles - the dumplings have shrimp and mushrooms, which are my faves!  Warm and comforting!  My bf liked his kung pao chicken too.  Plus, we ordered hot tea and it comes in these cool metal cups.  

They also have a nice bakery with lots of pastries with red bean, taro, pork (only $1 each!) - and lots of fancy cakes for your special occasions.
author: Maile N.

description:
We chose this restaurant because it's the only one that didn't need to wait on Christmas Day. However, it's the worst decision I've ever made.

Not to mention waitress are rude. The red bean in milk tea is not fresh and tastes weird. And the cabbage is not washed. We can clearly see dust and bad leaves. There's feather on the chicken. 

The worst thing is my boyfriend got food poisoning right after dinner. It's a really harsh night for us.

Please NEVER come to this restaurant.
author: Maxin C.

description:
Oh geez, stay as FAR away from this place as possible! Seriously.

After hitting all the tourist spots and failing to get any egg tarts from Golden Gate Bakery, we were all hungry. My aunt wanted to take us to a chinese place she always goes to, but they were closed for good and under remodel for a new restaurant. We then tried to go to ABC Cafe across the street and again, it was closed! Just our luck. Walked around and she decided to stop by Washington Bakery & Restaurant. I tried the assorted meat rice noodle, baked fish and porkchop in cream sauce over rice, and satay beef chow fun dry. ALL were horrible, lacked flavor .. tasted so plain. Cafe food for a little pricier than what it should be.

On top of that, the place was really dirty. Money was thrown on the counter (we were sitting right next to the cashiers office). We saw a waitress behind our table sneeze in one of her hands, then took a napkin to wipe her mouth and threw the napkin on the counter.. We all sat there in awe, disguisted not wanting to eat anymore. On top of that, the other table we were with had one order that they forgot to make.. so we had to wait a while to get that order. Bought 20 egg tarts from the bakery and the crust was more soggy than flakey.

RUNNN!!!!
author: Amy P.

description:
You would think Chinatown would have some of the best Chinese restaurants all around, not true!!!

A bunch of my co-workers and I came here for lunch due to the reviews here.  We came here around 1:15pm so the place was empty and we were seated right away. I ordered the Seafood Chow-fun, and everyone else ordered porridge.  I appreciated that they provided Chinese fried donuts with the porridge, and the dish was decent.  My chow-fun however, was bland and oily and their chili sauce did not help. My co-workers and I all got their bobba tea and the bobba was overcooked, slimy and gross.  Overall, steer clear from here and go to Panda Express instead.
author: Katie N.

description: Good for congee/juk and hot tea Hong Kong style. Mustard greens in garlic sauce aren't bad either. Very simple delicious food.  A must-stop here on every visit to the city.
author: Lis C.

description: Very good food and nice ladies who work there. The Cantonese style Chinese food is awesome, one stand out is the seafood (shrimp, squid, scallops) fried rice with only egg whites, porridge is always excellent.
author: N A.

description: The waitress was sweet and gave us milk tea for free! We came in for breakfast but were disappointed to find that their breakfast menu was very very limited. Their preserved vegetables and pork noodle soup was small, but it was still not bad, I guess. Their breakfast platter wasn't work the $5.75 at all, but my boyfriend settled on it because there was literally nothing else that sounded good to him. We only came due to the lack of places open at 9am, and that will probably still remain true in the future.
author: Christine C.

description: Walked over from Financial District Hilton for a quick to go option. I chose a BBQ pork bun, my husband egg and ham roll with coffee. Great! There is also a sit down restaurant. Suggested for a quick, affordable breakfast!
author: Susie C.

description:
Of the bakeries in Chinatown, the pastry display here (I feel) is the most clean. I usually stop by here if I'm in Chinatown to get about a dozen Ji Bao Dan Go (Paper Cakes/ Sponge Cakes). They're fairly big in size and really nice and fluffy. Sometimes I would get the Dan Tat (egg tarts) if I'm craving them as well. They're not the best in town but good if you don't want to make multiple stops.

I typically only get the pastries here since most are pretty good. The food and drink is very hit and miss depending on when you go. If you want to sit down and eat, you need to walk to the stand on the left to be seated. Typical sticky tables and questionable utensils. It's Chinatown for yas!
author: Kitty K.

description:
Breakfast review only.

My family and I dropped by for an early breakfast, and we found the place packed with people. They have breakfast specials for $4.50, which includes your choice of a variety of porridge (if you want to go the full Chinese route) or bacon/sausage with an egg and macaroni/oatmeal (if you want to go the... fusion(?) route). There are also some specials that are written only in Chinese, and those are more noodle-based dishes. Either way, no matter what you order off of the breakfast specials menu, you also get a choice of coffee or milk tea.

I went the American/fusion route (since I wasn't really in the mood for Chinese) and chose sausage with egg and macaroni. It's exactly what you would expect -- two pieces of sausage with an egg made to order how you like (I prefer mine over-easy) with a small bowl of cooked macaroni in chicken broth. And, being the milk tea junkie that I am, I ordered that for my drink. The meal is certainly nothing spectacular, but it's definitely not bad for the price. The milk tea is Hong Kong style -- my favoriteee.

In retrospect, I should have known better than to order American food at a Chinese place. Not to say it was disgusting (how bad can you mess up sausages and eggs?), but the porridge and noodle dishes were far superior.

All in all, decent portions and quick service. It's very much a get-in-eat-your-food-get-out kind of place.
author: Yvonne K.

description:
obviously the wantons in the 'roast duck wanton noodle soup' are either expired or whatsoever, it does not taste fresh at all. 
I finished about 1/5 of the soup, they charged me $9, but kindly enough offered me a free bread witch cost about $1.
will not stop here again for sure.
author: Cliff C.

description:
Food: I tried one of their Thursday daily specials, the beef chow fun. The noodles stuck together in lumps and there wasn't much beef. It's also very oily. The daily specials are about $8 and comes with a drink. I picked an iced ovaltine drink. The bottom of the drink was hot/luke warm while the top with the ice is cold. 

I also tried their pineapple buns from their bakery. They have 3 "mini" buns for $1.50. Pretty standard, just satisfied my craving.

I'm not too picky with these Hong Kong style cafes but this was a pretty disappointing.
author: Vio C.

description: I'm not a fan of heavy breakfast food, really. My roommate and I decided to try congee for the first time and it did not disappoint! Try the shredded roast duck porridge, it's so good. The food isn't heavy but it is very satisfying and left us feeling relaxed and pleasantly full.
author: Mariah G.

description:
Why 3 stars?  Because it was decent but I've had better.

   ---   ---   ---

After Dim Sum, what is the better sweet compliment than a Boba Tea?  I walked around Chinatown for a while looking for some until I found Washington Bakery.  I was in a nutty mood, so I went with a Coconut Boba Tea and a Coconut  Bun.  The Coconut Boba Tea seemed like it was missing a bit of sweetness.  Don't get me wrong, it wasn't bad, but I wouldn't rush to go back.  The Coconut Bun was like a donut with coconut shavings sprinkled on top.  How many times can you type Coconut on one review?  Coconut, coconut, coconut...coconut.  There, I reached ten, which is probably the quota.  

If you're in the mood for some Boba Tea and are surprisingly having a hard time finding some like I was, you could do worse than Washington Bakery.  The woman behind the counter was nice.  Visit for her.
author: Brett N.

description: The service is a joke. I'm ok if the waitress doesn't speak English well, but if she takes the wrong order, that's a problem, as we didn't get what we ordered. My son spilled his boba shake(glass cup)on the table, waitress walks past and does nothing. On top of that, she miscalculated the bill by overcharging us. Politely asked about the bill, and she rudely grabs the bill from my hand and gives us the corrected bill. Then on the way to the cash register she drops a dime and makes me pick up the dime as she pretended not to know, ridiculous. The food is actually decent, but I'd recommend going to higher priced restaurants in Chinatown or go to Chinese restaurants that are closer to the financial district.
author: Sam L.

description:
Bad attitudes
$1 for 1 little scoop of ice cream
Ask for tips few times
( I will give you tips but why the fuck you ask me to pay the amount that you ask me to pay.)
author: Ben W.

description: Went with my parents to grab a quick lunch. The service here is decent, but the quality of the food is horrible!! Both of my parents got wonton noodle soup, which they enjoyed. However, I got the chicken curry and it's disgusting. They give you good amount and it comes with onions, bell peppers, and chicken. The curry itself was watery and gritty, the chicken was cheap and thin. Also, the potatoes weren't fresh, I took one bite and it had a funny taste to it and had to spit it out. Would never come back.
author: Jessica N.

description:
Came here after doing some paperwork at the Taiwanese embassy a block away - bakery in front, and tables in the back.

Ordered some rice porridge with liver and gizzards and it was pipin' hot and delicious. Not too salty and not too watery, just the way I like it.

With complimentary coffee or HK milk tea, this place is casual, quick, cheap and cozy for those who love the Chinatown ambiance of old chinese man putterin' around getting their breakfast.
author: Zoe H.

description: Typical HK cafe. Has a large selection on the menu, but nothing is really it's specialty or is especially good. Perfect place to go to if you are looking for a quick fix for authentic HK food (yes, all the food there taste authentic) and don't have any particular dish in mind that you are definitely looking for.
author: Henry L.

description:
When you walk in, in the smell of a really complex brew of HK milk tea permeates the air, that mildly reminds me of the smell of the 5 leaf blend they use at the birthplace of HK milk tea where I stood outside a few weeks ago (at Lan Fong Yuen, sadly has turned into a major tourist destination for Chinese Mainlanders with slipping quality).

While the HK milk tea here is inconsistent (can be good if you are lucky), it seems that the HK western style side of the menu, i.e the baked proteins or sealife over carbs, is a much safer bet than the Cantonese side of the menu....which is ironic because the staff is entirely Chinese looking, or at least have some Canto or Toishanese roots.

They now charge 25 cents per to go cup or container.

The baked pork chop rice, while a rather fugly looking mess, and bordering on a tad too much sugar, is nonetheless better than nothing and surpasses everything outside of SF (with a few minor exceptions). This might just be even unhealthier than HK soul food in HK :-o

The dried fried beef chow fun (gohn chau ngau hor) is one of the worst jokes played to foodkind. Clumpy chow fun noodles in the vein of reheated American Chinese or Chinese supermarket steamtable fare that mostly broke apart, totally unprofessional crap stir fry job with hardly any wok way (despite it being served hot)...which is really odd given that we're in uhmmm Chinatown. Well who knows, maybe they re-stir fried steam table crap they purchased outside? Ho Hung Kee in Causeway Bay Hong Kong, would be really offended! Beef Chow Fail Fun.

So nice that Cooking Papa Foster City earned a Michelin Bib Gourmand listing. Good authentic affordable quality HK style food is indeed rare in all of SF Bay Area...too many cheap imitation wannabe's crawling around :-(

Bleh bleh toot toot!

The good news is....the protesting pro communist Chinese goverment grandpa is back! Same fella who stands on the stool for hours on the corner of Washington and Grant, and today held up a sign demanding Japan pay for reparations for WWII. Still belting out "happy happy happy!" and is still quite the gentleman. Seeing him again makes me happier than the sad stir fry chow fun job I had inside the bakery restaurant.
author: Ken K.

description: dan tat review only: They tried selling me leftovers at the end of the day another time at a discount, which I resisted thankfully, given their sad end-of-day appearance, but came back again at a normal time only to seal my disappointment. These are a little deceiving at first glance, but ultimately will only result in :(. Compared to GGB, these things are bland, lifeless. It may look like an ok flaky crust in the case, but one bite and you know you were wrong. The pale yellow custard and and more disturbingly light colored crust were my warning signs, but in the interest of the greater good, I ordered one. Yep, despite some sort of visible layers, it didn't flake apart with that toasted pie crust flavor and texture; no, it kind of tore softly - possibly underbaked? Anyway, the flavor overall was lacking. Skip this place for egg tarts.
author: Linus W.

description:
Washington Bakery is one of my favorite go to places in SF. After hanging out at the Metreon, I have walked to chinatown many times to eat here. It is that good. I don't live in the SF area but I love this HK style cafe. 

I usually order my favorite baked porkchop dish and wash it down with an hk ice tea. Delicious! Don't expect great service and fancy linens. Just expect simple and great food. Please don't compare it to Panda Express. 

Recommended! You can't go wrong giving it a try if you are in chinatown.  

Written via Playbook.
author: Jason L.

description: I'm from LA, and from the moment that I've stepped in the restaurant, the service was extremely poor. We called the waitress for tons of times and nobody response or answer. Then when we started to order, the waitress was lack of patience and she even left in the middle of the ordering session. The order came wrong and we didn't receive any apologies and the noodles was not fully cooked, I was born in HK so I know that the food isn't close to authentic. And eventually when we pay the bills, the waitress even ask for more tips. So we directly complained for all the ill manners and poor food quality. Never come back again!!! Strongly NOT RECOMMENDED!!!!!
author: Calista S.

description: Nice decent food. Nothing fancy but good food. If you are looking for a place to eat decent fried rice and noodles will recommend this.
author: Pam K.

description: Not what it used to be.  It's been a few years since I stopped by WB&R.  Not only was the food much worse than what I remember, but the prices were expensive.  Mum and I stopped by for an early lunch on Friday.  We were trying to beat the lunch crowd.  We ordered two dishes to share and Mum got a hot milk tea.  The first was ginger scallion lo mein.  The waitress didn't bring the soup that was supposed to come with the lo mein.  We didn't bother since the noodles were already a bit saucy from the hoisin sauce.  We also ordered a wonton, fishball ho fun.  The broth had no taste at all and was incredibly bland, leaving everything else to be bland especially the rice noodles.  The wontons were not that great and barely had any shrimp inside, mostly fatty pork.  When we asked the waitress for extra small bowls, since we were sharing, she flat out ignored us.  We ended up having to ask a different waitress.  The first waitress didn't come by when we also asked for tea refills.  In the end, the tab came out to be $22.  Pretty steep for what we ordered.  There wasn't even any meat on the lo mein for it to cost $9.  For what we ordered, prices incredibly high compared to other cha chan tangs.  I wasn't so bothered by the price, as I was with the waitress with attitude and bland/untasty food.  Will skip this place from now on.
author: Liv A.

description: Poor poor service!!!! Manager was rude to us beacuse we sat in front of bakery eating what we bought. They had a party of 4 wanting to eat their. Nice to have a prime spot in China town and dont care about service! They Suck!!! Food is also so so!
author: Peter G.

description:
Mmmmm I loved the egg tart here .. Came here because Golden Gate Bakery was closed .. 

But it was worth it .. 

They have mini pineapple bun !!!
author: Faith C.

description: I normally don't write reviews but this one is pretty bad.  I feel as if the waitress was strong arming us to give more in tips.  The service wasn't worth the tip that we gave.  When we tried to get her attention to get a bowl, she gave us a dirty look and also took a while for her to get to us.  Also she didn't seem friendly at all, but it's what to be expected in Chinatown.  The thing that pissed me off was the fact that when we paid our bill, she was standing over us and when we gave her a tip commensurate of the service, she insisted that we give her one more dollar since ,"we had two adults so it's a dollar per adult."  WTF?  Really?  Not ever going their again, even though my sister and I know the owners daughter.  Sorry, but with a wait staff like that, no thanks, and I'm probably going to tell my friends about the service and her attitude.
author: Philip L.

description:
My Son had the recent pleasure of meeting a few of his Facebook friends who live in Jordan. Both Moms have previously been in contact as the on-line friendship safely unfolded. The in person meeting went well and I was impressed and gratified on how well my Son and his friends got along and how much they had in common.  It was also a pleasure for me to meet the girls' Mom and Aunt as we met up recently in Chinatown. 

Even though we had all had Lunch before the meet-up, Teenage Kids still get hungry just a few short hours later. Hence, our entourage randomly stopped at the Washington Bakery & Restaurant for some snacks at the Counter or for me, just a soft drink from the fridge. My Son really enjoyed the pork buns here, but didn't appreciate being barked at by staff and their overall rudeness towards our entire well behaved Group. Maybe they didn't appreciate this this particularly diverse, yet nicely chaperoned entourage? Or the fact that one half-Arab Teen covered her hair?  My Son is very polite in these situations and even his appropriate responses of "Please" and "Thank You" were met my scowl-accented stares by Bakery Staff. I left happy that the Kids got fed and confirming that once again, bad service trumps good food.
author: Eric B.

description: My boyfriend and I ordered the spare ribs over rice and after a couple of bites I didn't want to eat it anymore. The plate hardly had any meat and mostly vegetables. It wasn't satisfying. This place sucks
author: Jenny H.

description: Great location if you're in chain town early in the morning only because Chinatown doesn't open until around 11. They have a great selection of tea and hot coffee! The front area is a bakery and towards the back is there restaurant. Not sure if this location allowed's ATM or cash only I didn't see any stickers indicating so... We were there around 9:15 AM just killing time before we went out to sightsee. Their selection of items are great and well priced. They had a great flow of traffic for 20 minutes we were sitting there.
author: Alexandra Linette S.

description: We eat here every Monday...funny haha the exactly same dishes every week for the last 2 years. Anna, the manager lady is super nice who knows our taste well and make some custom edition for us...its funny that she tried multiple times to sell us different dished however we were sticking with the same dishes. Anyways, its in Chinatown so don't expect a super clean and new fusion style but the food is great! Located right at the entry with the largest parking lot of Chinatown next to it, easy to park and go.
author: Wally L.

description:
I cannot believe that I have not written a review for this place after all the baked pork chop with tomato sauce and rice dishes, seafood crispy noodles, and jook bowls!  This place serves consistent Hong Kong style dishes, no complaints!  

Their mango cake is the best, must be pre-ordered!
author: C L.

description: Best clay pot ever!!!!!! Highly recommend pork rib clay pot:) no picture because I ate them all and it was tooooo delicious!!!!!!
author: Cynthia X.

description: Came here with friends after an event at New Asia. Food is yummy, and service is meh- typical for Chinatown. I had the wonton mein, and although it was yummy, I felt that the portions were smaller than usual restaurants, maybe it's because the prices are super cheap? $6.5 for 1 bowl of wonton mein. Don't try to share this bowl! It might be good if you were alright hungry; but if you were SUPER hungry, you'd probably need an hot dog bun or 2  to fill you up. Lastly, it was pretty convenient to get to. up the street from the parking lot underneath the park.
author: Elaine S.

description:
Probably one of the best restaurants in Chinatown. I actually thought the service here was pretty good considering the fierce competition in the area. I love the food options that I have on here which feel a lot like the restaurants in Milpitas of Asian fusion but with older Asian people. They serve really good hot milk tea which is useful on a rainy day like Christmas. The cups with the milk tea in them are evil. They steam at the top but when you touch them, it's room temperature. So I ended up burning my tongue thinking my tea wasn't as hot as it was.

They're really good with appetizers. The curry fish ball and pineapple dish was a really interesting. It hits the curry craving without the punishment from the carbs.

This place is usually busy but completely worth the noisiness and chaotic atmosphere. Unlike a lot of Chinese restaurants in SF, there's plenty of room to walk.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description: This place is an institution in chinatown for HK style cafes. For the people expecting fine dining with wait staff kissing your rear, this is not your place. The ladies here have been sweet to my family for the past 15 years. Be kind to them and see what that gets you. I always get the shrimp chow fun and congee...never been disappointed. The french toast is HK style which I love too. Bathrooms could use a renovation though!
author: Booger D.

description:
I met a friend here for a quick weekday lunch. She told me it's a noodle spot that's pretty popular among visiting Chinese parents. That said, I wouldn't say it's a place I would bring my parents for a nice meal - everything has that almost-sticky quality of a stereotypical Chinatown restaurant and it's also incredibly loud inside. The waitresses mostly speak Cantonese, but you can get by with menu item names. Don't expect superb service, because that's the authentic Chinese restaurant experience. However, they do take credit card! Hallelujah! They also sell Chinese-style bread ($1-2) in the front bakery part of the store. 

I got the Beef Tendon Noodle Soup ($6.95). They use the very skinny Hong Kong style noodles, which aren't my favorite but are authentic to Cantonese cuisine. The broth was not too heavily flavored but definitely was tinged with MSG. The portion size was perfect for lunch.

There are instant noodle options on the menu (yes, it was "instant noodles" in Chinese too). I'm not sure why you would order instant noodles for a 30x markup when you can boil some water at home. Whatever, Chinatown, I've stopped questioning you long ago.
author: Jessica F.

description:
This place has quickly become my favorite breakfast place in all of SF. It totally reminds me of those cafés in Hong Kong.Breakfast for five bucks including hot milk tea. 

The service is quick and no-nonsense. If you ever feel like you're missing Hong Kong, take a walk through the park adjacent to the restaurant and drop on in for a quick meal.
author: Mike P.

description:
Washington Bakery use to blow my mind away with their awesome tasting Chinese food.  Sooo...what happened to this place?  Could it be me?  Or was it the them?  The noodle bowls shrank, my Chanel wallet still likes it here but what about my taste buds?  Not so much anymore.  

I ordered my usual bbq pork won ton noodle soup.  The first thing I noticed was the size of the bowl.  No good.  So small.  Ah-ya.  And then when took my first slurp...  No good.  No flavor.  And then when I tried the bbq pork... Not good.  Taste funny.  What happened?

Normally, this place is jammed packed with the locals but not his time.   Sadly, I think I'm going to have to break up with Washington Bakery...
author: Jenny T.

description:
After reading many of the previous reviews, I was skeptical about eating here,  but I feel that this place is fine. 
Although cramped, seating is ample and the staff are kind. Most speak English and Chinese, which is common here in Chinatown, but always appreciated. The lynch specials all sounded great, but I got the Beef Chow Fun and chocolate milk. 
It took maybe 7 minutes for the food to get to the table, abs it smelled great! 
Overall, the food was yummy but they are very generous with the grease and oil. Fun environment and kind staff.
author: Sara T.

description: Good food and good service up until the end- Having had minimal service from a short but polite server, we left a small tip and were abruptly (and loudly in front of everyone in the restaurant) told to leave a bigger tip. Ben W is not kidding, this actually happens. While my mother obliged out of embarassment, I find this practice (I'm sure this isn't the first time) to be horrendous and rude and worth no more than one star.
author: Mel L.

description:
We tried the breakfast special (dine-in only). Price is okay at ~$4.50 including coffee or milk tea.
- Breakfast special #1: ham + egg + two pieces toast + macaroni. I think they took out the toast too early, it was still pretty soft. The ham and egg were swimming in a puddle of oil on my plate.. I tried to soak up as much oil as I could but the egg yolk burst while I was patting it with my napkin, sadly. It was a small bowl of macaroni in chicken soup; I cut up my ham and added it. I wish I chose the oatmeal instead of macaroni; would've been much more filling/worth it.
- Breakfast special #2: Porridge w/ preserved egg and lean pork. M didn't really like it.
- Milk tea: M thought the black tea was too strong but I thought it was okay.

Later we got take-out:
- Porridge w/ giblet: I didn't try this but my grandpa liked it enough to eat the whole carton.
- Porridge w/ chicken:We expected it to be boneless chicken meat and were planning on blending it all for my grandma, but the "chicken" was actually "chicken bone, fat and skin". Ew. There were also little shards of bone in the porridge..

Overall, the food isn't very good. I haven't tried any of their main dishes or bakery items though.
author: Ivonnie S.

description:
I never thought of writing a review in my neighborhood cafes.
Here in Washington cafe, I like their popular milk tea. It's strong, aromatic and comes in larger size cups than most cafes.

The beef and bitter Mellon dish is good.   Wonton noodles and beef brisket noodle soups are always good.   A few of their bakery buns are also good.   The rice cake with red bean paste filling, the coconut buns are good.

Breakfast specials before 11, they have a good selection of Chinese rice soups and donut with milk tea included for about 6 dollars.  A good deal considering the tea alone is 2 dollars if ordered separately.

I am not giving this place 4 star because some of the dinner selections are more a three to  three and a half star quality.
author: Doris A.

description:
My boyfriend and I used to go here all the time when were attending church in Chinatown. We've been attending a newer church outside of the city. We were in the city and decided to go back to this place.

It was just as we remembered, staff was nice and food came out hot.

My favorite dish is the sticky rice (lo mai faun)
author: Kathryn Y.

description:
Ordered Honey Walnut Shrimp, OX seafood fried rice and chicken.
Shrimp too soft and taste old, same as the chicken, hard to chew but the fried rice was decent.
Food: 2/5

Customer Service like all chinese restaurant but they make you tip them which is fine. But if you dont tip as much as they want they will demand more tipping, in which case its rude especially when the service wasnt that great and the food was horrible.
CS: -1/5

I give this restaurant 1 star and will never come back again. Horrible food and horrible experience.
author: Chuong V.

description:
Richard Pro here with another review.

Pretty solid and reliable location for piping hot and tasty food. I've had various things here: noodles, pork chop over rice, soup, and even their banana split. The banana split is huge and fresh. Their pork chop over rice is hot and delicious.

Their health score is 78 but meh, don't think anything in Chinatown is that clean. Service is acceptable at best. Never really had a friendly server with a great attitude here. In fact one waitress started talking smack about how little I tipped until I pointed out that the coins she was holding were $1 coins, not quarters.

Interior: it's pretty bright and I like how the tables are spaced. Unfortunately the tables and chairs are you typical old/worn out/sticky tables but meh. 

4 stars.
author: Richard P.

description:
they have a standing sign advertising cheap eats at lunch. when you are seated, they greet you but don't take your order.

after ten minutes, they come and tell you the prices posted outside don't apply now.

Buyer Beware!
author: Victor G.

description:
Note: This will be a review based on the bakery and cafe.

Restaurant:
Having tried HK style food back in NYC and actual HK food at Hong Kong itself, I have pretty high standards if I don't say so myself. I ordered the baked portuguese chicken with spaghetti. The dish of course took a while since it had to be baked, when it came the cheese was more like powdered on. It wasn't melted into the spaghetti. The sauce barely tasted like portuguese sauce. There was only potatoes and chicken. I was expecting peppers and mushrooms? Atleast that's what's served in NYC.. For the portion and quality of the dish, this place is overpriced. $8 for a teeny dish? One that's not even an authentic dish?

Cafe: 
I bought a birthday cake for my cousin. For an 8inch cake, you get grapes and peaches in your fruit cake and some strawberries, pineapple and honeydew on top. The cake was okay, it's nice being able to pick it up within an hour after placing an order. The cake was mostly cream though, but the sponge cake part was light and not overly sweet. There were barely any fruits. 

Overall I would say the bakery is a bit better than the restaurant. Prices are also more reasonable. Try to go elsewhere if you can, this place is definitely below average.
author: Virginia Y.

description:
11/3/13. Lunch

Eck. This place has gone downhill big time. It used to be my goto place when I needed a quick nosh on Chinatown. Compared to most Chinese joints in this part of town, Washington is well-lit and the bathroom is actually not nasty.

Anyhow...

*Wonton Noodle Soup ($6.95): the wonton wrappers are kinda thick sometimes I feel like chewing tortilla. Taste if wonton not bad, a nice balance between meat and shrimp. The soup is MSGish.

*Hot Lemon Tea ($2.75): what a nightmare. Tea is tasteless like the complimentary tea they give you. Do they know how it's served in Hong Kong?

So this is it. I'm not coming back. Yin Du on Pacific at Grant is much better. The lit wall panel is gone so the place is pretty dim. The TV that used to show live Hong Kong news is also switched off. Budget cut? New ownership?

Not good. No wonder the place is empty during lunch hour.
author: Matt Y.

description: Very very bad service! I ordered one coffee, one milk tea, one bread and one cookie. When I paid the check, the total price was more expensive than I expected, so I asked for itemized receipt. They just wrote down some prices on a paper, without detailed name of the food. Some of the prices were wrong, not the thing I ordered. So I talked to one of the server, she was very rude and said, " you've already eaten everything, how can I know what you ordered." It's ridiculous that they don't have formal record/receipt for the order. Everything is memorized by the server, which can be very inaccurate and they would never admit their mistake. Very disappointing!!!
author: Miya L.

description:
See my photo for breakfast review.

$4.50/includes fried dough with congee of your choice listed on menu. HK milk tea was decent but separate from the $4.50/tab.

They dont serve fried noodles until after 1030am.
author: Jboogie L.

description: Excellent choice for authentic dim sum! Great service and food. Should definitely visit here when you are in town
author: Jun-Han S.

description: You know what, i love it. I always come here for breakfast at least once when i visit SF. This past trip i went twice. Chinese donuts, jook, and a warm bowl of wonton noodle soup will get a day started on the right foot. Actually tried their coconut coffee which was almost like a dessert drink, and the hot soybean milk was just as comforting.
author: Johnny C.

description: Had breakfast here a couple of times and liked it. Simple Cantonese fare but tasty. Price was good and there something for everyone on the menu. Had a couple of the egg custard tarts and the were very good.
author: James R.

description: This was definitely my go-to place during my stay in SF. As many may have mentioned, it is a typical HK style restaurant. The one reason I would come here often is because of their breads and egg tarts. They were always fresh and good. I think I especially loved the ham & egg bread. Although the food is pretty good, I didn't find the workers to be very friendly. However, this could easily be avoided just by ordering to-go. I think I'll probably be doing that more often when I visit SF again.
author: Julienne T.

description: One of the first restaurants I came across when I moved to the city 10 years ago. Good, cheap food that comes out minutes after you order. The salty fish and chicken fried rice is especially delicious.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Washington Bakery has been a staple in my outside dining for well over a decade.  I've seen it go through a few changes, but the one constant is the excellent people that work here and their great service.

The first thing that you must know is that there are a lot of items on their menu.  It's rather mindboggling actually that they can create so many dishes.  My go to's are the baked spaghetti/rice, porridge, Shrimp Rice Noodles, Won Ton Roast Duck noodle in soup, and I cannot sit there without a milk tea.  The food is really good, and I can honestly say that so far every single item I have ordered has been excellent.  The prices has gone up through the years and I imagine that is highly due to the rise in cost of living and food cost.  However, still an affordable and considerably cheap place to go for dining especially with the high quality.  

Thank you Washington Bakery and being there!
author: Bernie C.

description: You know this place is  kinda special. Why? Because, everyone who was raised in, hung around in, or used to frequent Chinatown, knows that over the years, "the best food," has by and large left Chinatown for other areas around SF and beyond. The reasons for the exodus are many, among which is the fact that as the previous older generations of Cantonese immigrants (mostly from Hong Kong) families matured, the later generations moved out, taking with them an economic base that sustained good restaurants and quality food. The present inhabitants of Chinatown which replaced them, are recent immigrants from China that occupy a lower economic rung and cannot sustain the big fancy Chinatown eating palaces of old, (Empress of China, imperial Palace, Four Seas etc. all now closed or closing,) causing a reliance by these restaurants on the tourist trade and therefore a decline in the quality of the food.This reality, coupled with the fact that after the Golden Dragon Shooting several decades ago,and the closing, then opening and  "shrinking" of that popular restaurant, people just stopped coming to Chinatown to eat. That created the present void in Chinatown for anything but "HK cafe style" food, or take home BBQ and rice plate places (on Stockton St. The "local marketplace" street.) that are popular and preferred by the new generation of Chinatown residents, primarily  from South China. So when we can go out as a group of friends, as we did recently, and eat well in Chinatown these days, (anywhere other than the mighty R&G restaurant, the present Chinatown reigning king of good food,) it's a cause for celebration. And celebrate is what I would like to do, at a place that has withstood everything I mentioned for decades and is still going strong, turning out delicious dishes and Cantonese comfort food consistently, from a huge menu, with creative food choices, including some seldom offered old time Cantonese country classics. I am talking about Washington Bakery and Restaurant, on Washington St. across from Portsmouth Square, (the Chinatown Park and Garage). Care to take me out on my B'day? Bring me here please! And we will eat well, for a reasonable price, along with a restaurant completely full of local folks and others from all parts of Frisco, that know how to eat well. If it's lunch time, we'll order from their extensive lunch menu, all for around $7.50 for huge rice plates, noodle and other dishes. If it's dinner like I'm hoping, we'll be sure to order their famous signature "Wun Tun, chicken noodle," (sam wo win run gai) and salt and pepper squid, seafood noodles with egg, "sam pan jook", (three innard meats porridge,) salt and pepper fried tofu, (tzao daoufu,) Tofu and Beef pork, fried egg omelette with vegetables, Beef liver and vegetables, chinese greens, ox tail stew and finally chocolate blueberry cake to top it off. (This is a bakery too after all! All kinds od Cantonese and other yummy sweets and bakery goods in the front. If you you do that for me, I'll be sure to dedicate sushi g's next hit song to you. "I adore you...ta ta ta ta ta taaa ta"....nah not you... sorry....I'm talkin about Washington Bakery ya'll...
author: George F.

description: I like the HK style food. Ther service is fast and wonderful. I ordered the baked pork chop over rice which is one of my fav. One of the review mentioned that the gravy was a little too sweet, I also agreed. I would come back again.
author: Vay V.

description:
I had the veggie won ton noodle soup and for the life of me I could not tell how my won ton soup was any different from the won ton soup. There weren't any veggies in mine and the broth was flavorless. 

I was incredibly disappointed. Furthermore, the pics in the menu look very different from the items that are brought out. I understand the pictures are meant to entice the diner, but they should not be a blatant exaggeration.

It's possible that I ordered the wrong items off their menu, but that doesn't matter much because I will not return.
author: Keesy S.

description:
Of all of the other Cafe & Bakery Restaurants that, I have been to... This is my very first time ever to eat lunch on a very busy saturday at the Washington Bakery & Restaurant in the San Francisco Chinatown Area...

The food item that, I have order at this restaurant for the first time was the Shrimp & Chicken Fried Rice With 2 Kinds Of Gravy AKA Yin & Yang Fried Rice... I have eaten this before at South Sea Seafood Village and Go Go Cafe a while ago which both tasted pretty much as the same as the one like at the Washington Bakery & Restaurant...

The overall service from this restaurant was really good and the waitress who served me was very friendly and helpful... I will be back again on a different time to eat other item... I have also downloaded a picture of The Shrimp & Chicken Fried Rice With 2 Kinds Of Gravy so check it out!!!
author: William B.

description:
Porridge and Chinese Fried Bread for breakfast.  It doesn't get any more Chinese than this.

Oh wait, yes it does.  Chestnut Cake.

Coworker L and I had to open up the office today at 5 am, so by 7:30 both of us were starving.  One of the few open places was Washington Bakery, so I ran over for a porridge take-out.

A minced meat porridge ($5.50) and an abalone and chicken porridge ($7.00), plus an order of Fried Bread ($1.90) later, we're both happy, full, and convinced of our Chinese heritage.  The porridge was a good consistency and chock full of meat, but the fried bread wasn't crispy like I was used to; instead, it was just a soft, doughy, greasy bread, like underbaked French baguette that had been dropped in the fryer for a quick second.

Early morning is the cleanest you'll ever find these Chinese restaurants, so if you're a sucker for cleanliness, go in the morning.

They have a huge selection of food: breakfast items, noodle dishes, soups, and HK-style stuff like baked spaghetti.  Their bakery items are also fresh and varied, and if you've never tried Chestnut Cake, I highly recommend it (although I don't know if this one's good or not - the last time I had it was like 15 years ago, and I loved it).  It's like a birthday cake, but with only a slightly less sweet, nutty flavor to it.

OH, AND THEY TAKE CREDIT CARDS.

Credit card machine ftw.
author: Tori S.

description:
This place can be an Asian Jekyll & Hyde to me.
I've had some good meals there and others were meh.
And then I would have the same dish on different occasions that were different.

For example, the baked pork chop over rice was great on my first try, but then on another visit, it tasted odd - like something synthetic in the dish. The HK style fun with beef was pretty good I remember. Won ton noodle soups seems to have a high MSG content, although it was flavorful, ha.  I've always had good desserts here, so that earns an extra star.
author: Derek N.

description:
This place has gone completely downhill since I was a kid and it first opened. 

I used to come here almost every saturday morning as a kid with my dad for breakfast. Meals were cheap and good. Now the quality of the food has went down and prices are just so so. 

Just a few weeks ago my boyfriend's dad bought a coffee cake from there and it was absolutely terrible. I don't know what they soaked the fruits in, but it was completely BLAND. No taste at all. Not sour. Not sweet. Absolutely nothing, it wasn't even edible, had to spit it out. The cake portion was also must meh. 

Don't count on me to come back here.
author: Harriet W.

description: I was a little disappointed at the breakfast after reading many good reviews. I would have given 3 stars for their breakfast but their fresh made mooncakes are very good.
author: Danning X.

description:
This is my safe place to go to when I can't figure out what to eat in San Francisco. Their service is OK here IF you can speak chinese. It may take a little longer if you don't because their English is really poor. 

In the front of the store, they have a few chinese bakery goodies that you can order. It's no so bad. I always order their pineapple buns. They make it pretty good here.

As for lunch, they're pretty popular on the noodle dishes. I always order the roasted duck egg noodles. It's good, fills me stomach, and does its job. It's also pretty affordable. It won't rob an arm and a leg to eat here.

TIPS: There's always a line for the baked goods and the restaurant. Make sure you're vocal if you want to eat there. And try their noodle dishes. :)
author: Leena N.

description: This restaurant seems to be a really popular spot at Chinatown. I visited here after hearing nice things about the Hong Kong style milk tea, but the milk tea is a disappointment to me. What surprises me is the stewed beef with tomato over rice though. The plate is huge with two portion of rice. And the beef with tomato is so good that I finished all the rice! Two drawbacks: 1. This restaurant is so popular that you have to wait for quite a while before the dish is served. 2. A little bit pricy compared to other similar cafeteria in Chinatown
author: Vivian Y.

description: Very mediocre baked pork chop over rice. Too sweet for my taste and rice tasted a little old. Still can't find a place that beats or matches the baked pork chop at Venus Cafe in Newark...
author: Dominic G.

description:
My husband got food poisoning from this place last Fri, 8/17!

He ordered the bbq pork wonton soup and one of the women who works there said to him (in Chinese), "Tastes bad?" as she walked by, not knowing he understood what she was saying. He said there was shrimp in the wonton that tasted off and now wishes he'd spit it out. His stomach started gurgling after that meal and that's never a good sign.

He's finally feeling better four days later after a lot of throwing up, diarrhea, a visit to the ER, a four hour IV drip to re-hydrate him and a round of anti-biotics.
author: Julia T.
