description:
Got the following:

2 Curry pastries
Baked BBQ pork bun
Coconut custard bun

Overall, pastries were good, but a bit greasy.
BBQ pork bun was tasty and lots of meat
Coconut bun was great, dim sum quality.

the bakery was very busy, next time I go there I'm going to try some of their food.

Good for cheap baked goods.
author: Rob L.

description:
Came in for a quick bite.  Got the wonton noodle (a staple to measure).  Not impressed.  They also offered HK style noodle but it turned out to be the SAME noodle, so false advertising....

Service is slow too.  I like the idea of a bakery on the side...so while I don't like the restaurant as much, the bakery may be different.
author: Sonny W.

description:
This is my all-around favorite place in Chinatown! Mouth-watering food for a very reasonable price! People love this place and it shows cuz it's always super busy. Waitresses maybe abrasive, so be prepared to order quickly, but heck, whatever you order is bound to be tasty!

I recommend the baked peppered pork chops over rice. No one else in the Bay Area makes it this good!
author: Robin H.

description:
Decent spot for a quick lunch. Washington Bakery & Restaurant is a HK style bistro with expansive menu items. 

Daily specials come with one lunch menu and a drink (hot/iced tea with lemon or honey lemon). I like the Thursday special which is Yi Mien or E-fu noodles with pork. It's a stir-fried flat egg noodles with pork and white chives. The honey lemon tea and milk tea are rather sweet. I've also tried the tofu claypot with salted fish. I wish the salted fish can taste and smell a bit stronger.

Big portion and cheap. It's a quick fix for my Cantonese food craving.
author: Saran R.

description: The food was good. But the service was ok. The bread from the front desk was fresh. The mike tea and wanton noodles is great either. If you guys are from Hong Kong or Guangdong, you should understand.
author: Kingkin W.

description:
hardcore cantonese tea cafe place... 

a little greasy, not the friendliest place... but not bad for what it is really
author: Jeanette Y.

description: I wanted my friends to take me here but made it in myself it was rather nice because good food and drink at a very low price considering it being better than what I see in San Jose
author: Michael W.

description:
This place is good for a fix of Chinese food. We usually get some combination of a chow mein, calamari, jook, or fried rice. The only time I've had to wait for a table (and only because we were already there and the wait was only 10-15 minutes) was a hot sunny Saturday.

The atmosphere is super casual, and ++ for the mini pastries that they sell in the front of the store.
author: Adele Z.

description:
I'm eating while writing this review

We ordered a black pepper beef chow mein - pan fried $8

It was pretty yummy. Noodles were crispy and beef was tender but a bit chewy. 

The pork potstickers  $6 were awful. Very oily, the skin was thick so the little meat it had was not tasty.
 
The service was prompt, not stellar. But can't expect a lot of good service in Chinatown. Like always parking was a nightmare. Although there is a Parking lot nearby for $3 an hour.
author: Mily W.

description:
Ok. When I gave this place four stars, it was for eating here on a weekday. Do not go to this place on a busy Saturday. They are so damn understaffed that we didn't get ANY attention while sitting there for 10+ minutes. Tried to flag down the youngest of the 3 ladies working and all she did was stare at me and continue walking off. When I told her we were ready to order, she simply said that she doesn't do that. No effort to find somebody to does take orders or even reassure that somebody will come over soon. They don't give a shit how long you've been waiting. We just got up and left. Their cheap breakfast is not worth sitting through horrible service for. 

tl;dr DON'T COME HERE ON THE WEEKEND. SERVICE SUCKS BALLS. Weekdays are ok.
author: C. Z.

description: I came across this place as looking for a breakfast place. I ordered their pork congee and hk style milk tea. Both taste like what I had in Honk Kong. Highly recommend!
author: Anna L.

description:
A whiff of the milk tea brought out a satisfyingly rich earthy aroma. For a second, I thought this was going to be one of those rare times when I randomly find a good milk tea. Unfortunately, the aroma was more tantalizing than its flavor. Womp womp. It's not a terrible milk tea, but it's not as strong as it should be. Without a really bold brew, the flavor fell flat. The creaminess and sweetness don't really matter if the tea isn't bold enough. Maybe I went on a bad day. At least it smelled pretty good. 

The wonton noodle soup here was actually better than I expected. The wontons were nice and plump, with wholesome shrimp inside to give it a nice firmness to contrast with the softness of the skin and pork. The stuffing was well seasoned, and the spices imparted a pleasant warm fuzziness. The spices are very crucial to wontons. Nothing is more aggravating than biting into a wonton with dull stuffing, and it occurs much too often for a city filled with so many Chinese people. Another surprising aspect of the dish was the noodles. They had a very desirable Chinese al dente texture which gave the noodles a nice bite. It'd be a complete dish if only the broth was made correctly, which was pretty much just plain watery chicken broth. There's no sign of the dried seafood flavors that enrich the broth with the umami-ness required to infuse continuous flavor in every slurp. Without the broth, the wonton noodle soup falls short. 

I just have to say that I also found the bowl very amusing. There's a handle on the side of it that lets you pick it up to drink the soup. Although I didn't find it that tasty, I found myself drinking the entire bowl just because I wanted to use the handle. Genius!

I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, but if I'm in the area, I might stop by again.
author: Nei N.

description:
It's odd to me that soup dishes would take forever to come out.  I mean I got my Mongolian Beef dish before my parents and sister got their soups.  I also watched as some individuals who got there after us, ended up getting their soup dishes first.  

Not only that, but their noodle dishes were so bland -- It's like eating noodles in a no-salt broth. We didn't get any tea refills and they don't validate.  Drives me crazy that no one around Chinatown validates!

After we left, my dad went back in to use the restroom and they told him, "sorry, only for customers".  I was actually next door buying sesame balls, so I didn't get a chance to do anything about that.  I was pretty pissed when I found out.  

It was a BLIND FIND which I regret. Be prepared for an unhappy lunch or dinner. 

PS: There isn't really a good selection of Chinese pastries here. Move on.
author: Moua L.

description:
I've never tried the food here, but I love the bao and the other Chinese baked goods!  

Overall, the desserts are reasonably priced, and the variety's decent.

You can get 3 mini pineapple bao for $1.25.  I personally think this is a better value than the big pineapple bao, since they're not *that* much smaller.
author: Alice C.

description:
When I was young, my dad would always drop me and my sisters off in Chinatown hours before we had school and would give us 20-30 dollars of survival money. If we're feeling for some Pho, we would go to Golden King, Star, Flower, or whatever is golden. Anyways, when we're feeling for some Chinese food before hours of torment in school, we would instantly choose Washington Bakery.

We would always eat the Baked Pork Chop Over Rice or their Stir Fried Noodle with Beef. Occasionally we would even order something as simple as Beef Fried Rice. Heck, I even remember ordering their Creamed Corn/Egg/Chicken over rice. Whatever it was, it tasted good. I don't ever remember having an unpleasant time here. Ever.

Anyways, Washington Bakery will always be a favorite when I'm around Chinatown. BRING BACK THE LITTLE CORN SHAPED EGGETTES! I really liked those...
author: Eric M.

description:
Meh, the only reason why I still come here is because my entire family and I have been coming here since I could walk. Whenever were in SF we eat breakfast here....why? Its convenient and they have traditional Hong Kong style dishes like:

-Beef chow fun
-Preserved egg porridge/congee
-Wonton soup
-War wonton soup
-Yellow noodle duck soup

The portions are tiny...why?! Chinese folks are cheap...lol no really their food is very well portioned. I've never tried anything from the bakery and the service is so so. Meaning by so so...one time the waitress we had must of crawled out of someone's ass because her service was horrible and she was rude!!!!!!! We decided to tip her $1.00 for our $10.00 snack and she had the audacity to stop us and ask for more!!!!!! I was shocked and I wanted to give her a piece of my CHINESE mind!!!!  My cousin ended up giving her another $1.00 since she was DESPERATE for it!!!! WOW WOW WOW!!!!!!!! 

P.S. I don't like the cups they serve their tea in. They are ugly disgusting silver metal mugs that when you drink your tea.....you can taste the METAL! EWWWW. Oh, one more thing...they don't bring you a pot they always serve you ONE CUP for EACH person.
author: Annie P.

description:
(See pics)

Princess chicken is very delicious. Meat is tender and juicy.

Also came here for congee in the morning, very tasty and freshly hot.

During Mid Autumn Festival, my absolute favourite festival, the restaurant also carries its own mooncakes. The egg yolks are okay but the base is really good. Grin.

Service is good and nice. They make the dishes pretty fast too.
author: T L.

description:
If you really love hong kong style milk tea you should try this place.
I go here to get milk tea every weekend with my bf.
He is from hk. Haha. 
When his sister visited us we took her here.
They said the food here is somewhat above average. 
But I do not recommend their bakery because they don't put enough filling ( but they are not expensive. )
Oh! They have breakfast items $4.50(?) including milk tea.
author: SS K.

description:
This place is basically a Hong Kong style cafe combined with a Hong Kong style bakery.

I ordered a pork-chop baked spaghetti with tomato sauce. I think most Italians would be offended by what Cantonese people consider baked spaghetti to be, but this is how they make pasta in this type of restaurant.

The pork-chop was breaded and very tender and covered in tomato cream sauce. I would say that the sauce was more like cream with a splash of tomato. The plates and silverware is of the low cost variety and the prices here reflect that.

I also ordered a Hong Kong milk tea here too. The best one I've ordered in a long time. It reminded me of why I don't like boba milk tea.

Didn't try anything from the bakery. Maybe next time.
author: Glen L.

description:
I love this place. I have been several times and every time the food has been perfect. My usuals are the fish congee and the beef chow fun but the clay pots and rice dishes (Hainanese chicken rice and sticky rice) are delicious as well. The wonton noodle soups are not bad either. Great place either for lunch or a casual dinner.

Be warned - don't come within the closing hour of the restaurant (starting around 7:30pm or 8pm). They will rush you like crazy and practically throw you out of the place. This has happened twice to me now and it's the only reason why I wouldn't give the place 5 stars.
author: Brittany L.

description:
3 stars except for its great location.

This review is about the bakery part only. The taro pearl milk tea, and drinks in general, took a long time to make. Well, longer than I'm used to and it wasn't even crowded. Still, it was good during a sunny day in SF. Another popular drink was the honeydew. Besides a large list of drinks, there individual slices or whole cakes and pastries. The sponge cakes are very popular with little kids, as they wolfed them things down like their parents don't feed them. :D

Literally only a few steps away from Portsmouth Square in Chinatown, the bakery is at the front and a whole noodle-house was in the back. The girls working there were friendly. Will return the next time in the area, yeah.
author: Peter L.

description:
yummy hong kong style french toast with Red bean ice are perfect for a hot day!

The french toast is crispy on outside and soft inside!  The red bean is tender and just the right taste!  It reminds me  of Hong Kong cafe!
author: Coco L.

description:
Welps.  I was expecting to dish out four stars, I'm a fan of HK style cafes.  However, the baked seafood and ying yang fried rice just weren't good.  This is Chinatown, so I can't really bump up another star for affordability... their neighbors are equally affordable.

Better luck tomorrow. 

Or in the Outerlands.
author: Erika C.

description:
We came here for a quick dinner on our first night in San Francisco.  They have a small bakery in the front, and a large seating area in the back.  This place is what I would describe as HK style cafe, kind of like your American diners.  We were tired and we just want to have a quick bite and be on our way.

I chose the portuguese chicken baked rice.  My friend ordered the eggplant and pork chop clay pot with a side of chinese broccoli in oyster saue.  My other friend had the mongolian beef.  The mongolian beef came in  a huge serving.  It was spicy and flavorful.  The eggplant and pork chop clay pot came out bubbling.  You have to order a side of rice as it doesn't come with the dish.  It was really filling, but at the end of the dish, we were left with a vat of oil.  The chinese broccoli was your one of he mill veggie.  Nothing special.  The baked rice dish was really disappointing.  It had no flavors.  Not as saucy as I remember portuguese chicken baked rice as.  

The best thing I had there were the pineapple bun that I got for breakfast the next day.  It was still soft and yummy the next morning.  I didn't have to warm it up at all.  Flaky on top and with a coconutty filling in the middle.
author: Maggie Y.

description: I brought my friends here for the New Year's weekend.  I've been here before, so I know what to expect.  Just letting you guys know, this place is not the cleanest... as expected.  Also the service ain't the greatest... as expected.  Finally, they don't speak English (you can get by with english) very well as expected.  So, prepare if you decide to come!  We had the congee with fried chinese donut, beef with scrambled eggs, pork chop baked rice with tomato sauce, and shrimp baked rice with white sauce.  We also tried their Hong Kong milk tea which was pretty good.  The portions are on the larger side - you'll definitely get stuffed with the baked dishes.  I didn't like the shrimp one, it had a funny taste to it - sadly my friend got food poisoning later that day!  The congee was pretty typical, can't really go wrong.  The pork dish was OK, we've definitely had better.  Overall, this place is just OK, but definitely cheap.
author: Kevin N.

description:
Where do you go for a quick, cheap breakfast in Chinatown? No, I'm not counting those bakeries where most customers get a bun and run. I'm talking about sit down, read an actual menu, and ordering something that requires utensils. This is my spot. They offer a $4.50 special menu from 7:30 am to 10:30 am everyday (warning: dine-in only). There are three menu options for $4.50 as follows: 

Option A 
Bacon, Sausage, or ham (note singular) with one egg (choice of how done), and Oatmeal or Macaroni and Toast - Choice of coffee or milk tea (nai cha) - popular Hong Kong beverage combining house tea (usually red tea) with coffee cream or half and half; add sweeteners to personal liking. 

Option B (menu, half in English, half in Chinese) 
1. Preserved Egg & Pork Porridge 
2. Minced beef Porridge 
3. Assorted pork giblet Porridge 
4. Meat ball Porridge 
5. Pork Liver Porridge 
(all above served with Chinese Fried Bread - yiao tiu) 
6. Ground Beef Vermicelli Soup 
7. Spam and Instant Noodle Soup 
8. Snow cabbage & shredded Pork Vermicelli Soup 
9. Ham and Macaroni Soup 
10. Shredded Chicken and Macaroni Soup 
(this portion of menu is written in Chinese only) - includes coffee and milk tea beverage. 

Option C 
Instant Noodle - add your choice of three items from the following: 
a) beef stew, b) beef tendon, c) pork intestines, d) pork blood, e) stewed egg - slow boiled in soy sauce, f) chicken wing, or g) lettuce 
- includes coffee and milk tea beverage (entirely in Chinese on menu) 

I am fortunate to have a coworker with the patience to translate this for me so I know my full options the next time I'm there. No, it's not a culinary adventure or place to impress; but tell me where you can get this many choices at this price. Having eaten breakfast one block away at the Hilton, this is certainly a meal that's a lot easier on the pocketbook. 
My favorite here is their fresh watermelon juice, great on those warm summer days. It's a little pricey at $3.50 per cup (12 to 16 oz.), but it is both sweet and flavorful, complete with pulp. They also make a large variety of tapioca pearl drinks. You order these at the pastry counter. One of those, if you're in the neighborhood kind of places... and just around the corner from Golden Star Vietnamese Restaurant.
author: Mike C.

description:
Lunch time favorite if I'm feeling like HK style Chinese food. My friend was sick so she wanted soup and I wanted my rice noodles. I also had to pick up a cake for my boss' birthday so it was a total win-win situation for all. Service is usually pretty good and fast. Bakery items here are good too.

- Chicken & Veggie Soup: tasty broth with variety of asian veggies
- Shrimp & Scrambled Egg Rice Noodle: good as always - one of my favorite dishes!
- Fruit Sponge Cake: moist, not too sweet, lots of fruit, and tons of whipped cream
author: Linda C.

description:
Decent noodles and milk tea. 

The Seafood and Mushroom Chow Mein is really yummy!
My mom had the Wonton Mein. Also yums.
author: Melissa T.

description: Ordered wonton noodle soup and chow mein. They were both okay, not something that blows my mind. It's like homemade Chinese food. As for the bakery, I have not had it yet... Usually I go to Golden Gate Bakery instead.
author: Arvin C.

description:
This is the only place in SF Chinatown that I'd ever eat. Much cleaner than other places and the food is GREAT. Salt and Pepper Chicken Wings are a must get. My usual is the Lemon Iced Tea and Roast Duck WonTon soup, amazing!!

They also have amazing buns that they bake fresh everyday, as well as beautiful cakes. Service is friendly and great. 

If you're ever in Chinatown, go to Washington Bakery and Restaurant!!
author: Christopher H.

description: Good place for jook. Really tender pork giblets in the jook. Not fancy, but it isn't supposed to be. It is a local place.
author: Mich L.

description: No star for this restaurant. I went for lunch w my family i had order a chicken w black bead sauce over rice and the chicken was not fully cook. I told the waiter and she say it's cooked the chicken is like that and she just walk away. The service was so bad I couldn't even get the waiter attention. And couldn't get the order right and food is not cook. So then I forget it, I asked for a check n I give less tips cuz the service was so bad. While I was walking out the cashier lady stop me and say hey it's not enough. I was like what are you talking about? She say u missing $1 dollar. I told the casher lady that I had paid enough she kept saying no it's not enough u need to put one more dollar. I didn't want to argue with her so I just give her the dollar n I just tell myself I'm not going back at all. Food and service very bad.
author: Mina C.

description: Based on a friend's suggestion, headed here bc GG was closed for vacation.  Thankfully the dan tat (custard tarts) were warm, flaky crusts filled with silky (not too yolky) custard to satisfy my yearning.  + only $0.80/each - cheaper than GG.  Bought a pineapple bun & coconut custard bun but too full to eat them yet.
author: Kim S.

description:
Again, where did my original review of this place go to? Anyway, I never liked the food here, so we didn't eat here, but we did have drinks. We had wanted to take it to go but the lady at the cashiers was really nice and offered us a seat.

I got the 'leung fun ping' (grass jelly ice) w/o sugar and milk. Hubby got the coconut milk coffee. The young man tried the coconut milk coffee and liked it and ended up getting himself a cold one.

I thought they were really accommodating because the coconut milk coffee didn't come in a cold drink version but they made it for us anyway.

I wouldn't come for the food, but the drinks are good!
author: Anita L.

description:
party: 2
ambiance: casual
money spent per person: $5-$7
service: unfriendly

I've been here countless times for Saturday morning breakfast with my mom. As much as I love the buns from the bakery and the toast meals, I have to give them only 2 stars for bad service and quality of food. I recently ordered the shrimp rolls and noticed that the entire roll was saturated in oil. So oiled up that it shined in a disturbing way. Also, the soy sauce that it comes with had a thick layer of oil. My mom's bowl of wonton noodle soup was lacking in substance and only had a few wontons and a couple strands of noodles. Perhaps we're used to the good food treatment in the south bay, but we were extremely disappointed with the waitresses' attitudes.
Also, we heard two of the waitresses gossiping about a non Chinese speaking customer loudly... which is just disrespectful! However, I do love the baked goods, especially the egg puffs when they have them!
author: Anita L.

description: Never come to this place if you want good and value chinese food! The food portion is small and expensive. I bought a beef chow fun for $10.20, where other places only charge less than $8. Plus the food is bad, the place is dirty and don't let me start on their customer service. Very disappointed!
author: Jake Z.

description:
Upscale prices, poor service, mediocre food. 

This is my second time to this place and I really did try to give it a chance.

The first time, the service was EXTREMELY poor. When I didn't put down any tips, they chased after me as I left and ASKED for it!!! Can you believe that??

Expect to pay double the price of any other place you find in Chinatown. This place is a tourist trap because it's right next to the parking lot at Portsmouth Square and The Hilton. I'm no tourist but it's a fair warning for those that wander by on an empty stomach. 

The service is extremely slow even with a restaurant that is less than a quarter full. (late lunch) I even had to personally walk up to the counter to pay. They don't walk around refilling water or tea like other places.

The food its not AWESOME, the quality wasn't up to par for the price you pay. My wonton soup tasted like they poured an entire bottle of sesame oil into it. To make matters worse the portions were damn small. 

I felt full the entire day after lunch, not because it was big meal, but I prob. caught something. O yeah, my friend that was eating with me also had some problems afterwards.

NOT COMING BACK!
author: Felix L.

description:
This bakery is one you will not miss especially if you park at the washington square parking garage. 

I think they serve great pastries and buns but they seem to overprice them a bit compared to all the other bakeries in chinatown. 

They also serve a lot of hong kong style cafe foods here too, so they're got the whole package. They also have milk tea of course, cant forget that.

I like their won ton soup, which is probably the only thing i ever get here. i dont think they can ever screw that up! But, because of their bump up in prices, i'd have to subtract an extra star
author: Kenny L.

description:
came here for breakfast and bad service like rude and mean. doesnt check what else you need when u dine in. 

the food is cheap tho for their prices. but its mediocre.  nothing special like good or bad about it.
author: Alex T.

description: I enjoy ordering the sticky rice here. A wide variety of drinks and dishes you can choose from. Great Hong Kong style Chinese food.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Got here at 10:25am on a Saturday morning with my sister to meet my cousin and his wife. 5 minutes before the breakfast menu closed. Whew.

The serving lady first gave us the regular menu, but upon request, she gave us the breakfast menu that we had traveled here for. Thankfully, she still accepted our order as long as we ordered right away.

I got the 4.50 combo with hot milk tea, sausages, oatmeal, scrambled eggs and two pieces toast. Yes, lots of variety, but not big portions, which was fine with me since I didn't want to stuff myself.

Everything tasted pretty good. Service was ok. Nothing was EXCELLENT but the low prices were exciting. Located right within bustling SF Chinatown so there's stuff to look at.
author: Katherine K.

description:
This review is solely for the won ton noodle soup I had here last time.

Came here during lunch hour from work and was quite busy. We were seated right away though and they had an extensive menu to choose from. I already knew I wanted some kind of soupy dish so I went with the BBQ pork won ton noodle soup. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/aHnXmu0YUUg5WW_ERihxTw?select=ty08sHv4ZI1-poEAjODycA)

The noodles were too undercooked for me which made it difficult to eat but the won tons were huge and filled with shrimp/pork meat. The BBQ pork was yummy and tender too! The soup was just like regular chicken stock, nothing special. Service was "eh" but what do you expect from a cheap restaurant in Chinatown?

It was an ok meal but I have tons of other options to try if I ever return.
author: Karen Y.

description:
I can't say i've had better because i've never had wonton noodle soup from anywhere else. 

You're in Chinatown so if you're expecting panda express you will be disappointed. I've been going to Chinatown since I was a kid. Lugging around bags of Chinese sausage and veggies is hard work so its necessary to get some kind of nourishment before all the shopping begins.

Dim sum and Washington bakery were the only places my dad would take me to for breakfast in Chinatown. I always get won ton noodle soup and hong kong milk tea. The noodles are a little bland add some pepper and  you're good to go. The Hong kong milk tea is really good I mean you cant really go wrong with condensed milk. It does have a flavor that is different than your average milk tea but I enjoy it.

This may not be the cleanest place on earth but hey it's a pretty good choice if you're in Chinatown!
author: Sarah C.

description:
The Good-
The dining room is cleaner than average but slightly dated.
The bathroom is up to McDonald's standards.That's saying alot.
Commerical quality toilet and sink plus industrial tile with floor drain.

The Bad-

Not much soul but legit like going to a Chinese Dennys.
Not good old Chinatown cheap and big greasy portions.
Their food is good and their prices are fair.

It's a safe place to eat at but not an adventurous place.

It's not particularly touristy...even though it's a stone's throw from the Portsmouth Square. There were actually quite alot of mainstream Chinese people eating there...even older folks...so I guess there is level of sanitation consciousness in the clientele's minds.

Times are changing.
The place is low key and not trendy.

I miss dirt cheap and kinda dirty but so Delicious.
It was good but not THAT good.
author: Winston W.

description:
The baked pork chops was pretty good. It has almost like a sweet n sour ketchup type of sauce over it sitting on top of fried rice. The salt n pepper wings were good too. The chow fun was ok. Definitely had better at most other places I have been to. The fried fish balls were a big disappointment. I thought it was bigger, but they were tiny. It didn't even taste fried. This is an alright place. Decent enough if your hungry.

It was pretty clean in there which was a plus.
author: Kimberly L.

description: If you must have good service when eating in a restaurant, then don't come here. If you're hungry early in the morning and want a quick, cheap decent Chinese congee, misc. noodle & soup - then come here.  This is your typical Cantonese restaurant, so Hong-Kong style rudeness is expected.  Breakfast for 4 is around $20.
author: Fred I.

description:
My friend Chuck had come to visit a number of years ago and we were wandering though chinatown with Susannah B hungry at 3 in the afternoon.  Now I had had a horribly bland meal before at a very fancy touristy chinese eatery down the block that sported a picture of "Yan Can Cook" at the doorway as an endorsement... apparently he can cook but has no taste buds.

Walking around I peered in to this bakery only to notice a good number of tables toward the back, most of which were filled with asian looking people at 3 in the afternoon.  The specials were written on a dry erase board in chinese only and you could see the cooks busy in the kitchen passed the long serving counter that ran most of the length of the restaurant.  At that moment I knew I had struck pay dirt!

The meal we had was fabulous and cheap.  I have since been back there at least a hundred times, bringing new people with me as often as I had the opportunity.  This place is one of those hidden gems in the city.  My favorite dishes are their salt and pepper cod, beef porridge,  and salt and pepper spareribs, and their chinese broccoli in oyster, garlic, or whatever sauce strikes my fancy.  It also seems that whenever I go with other people I end up trying something new that I love.

We left that place fat and happy and I always look forward to going back.  I am a fan!
author: Theron L.

description: I always.... I mean always crave the wontons from here. To the point where I'm willing to drive from SJ to SF, if someone's willing to come along.
author: Dan L.

description:
Love this place! Mostly because of the buns. I don't usually sit down and get a meal, but if you actually want to eat there, i recommend that Stir-Fried Udon with Vegetables dish. It is pretty tasty and hearty but a little oily. I also enjoy their congee and chinese donuts. 
 
The buns are the main reasons why this restaurant/bakery is great in my opinon. Just get those paos! Usually $1 each for almost every single bun they sell. Easy and cheap snack, here I come!
author: Alex L.

description:
Had lunch here recently based on the suggestion of a couple workers as where to get inexpensive lunch near the Financial District.

I ordered the Baked Seafood with cream sauce over rice.  I wasn't very pleased with my order as it seemed more like baked rice and cream sauce garnished with a bit of shrimp.  Only seafood in the dish were little shrimp and those were scant.  I guess I shouldn't be expecting much because of how inexpensive the dish was...but still, why call it a seafood dish when there's only one kind of seafood in it?  Also, it wasn't really baked...more like rice plopped in the dish, smothered it with cream sauce, topped with little bit of shrimp and a dash of some shredded cheese and then but in the oven to melt the cheese just a tad.  

Only thing I did really like is their Hong Kong style milk tea...mmm.

So, okay my lunch experience wasn't exciting, but their breads and cakes looked interesting.  I'm considering to use them for their baked goods when I place my next company breakfast order from a Chinese bakery.  Til then...3 stars for now.
author: Michelle N.

description:
All you need to know: $1 egg and ham croissant.

Who needs another $3 bagel or muffin when you're in a rush to work?

Don't even think about trying to take a picture in here, but the baked good are pretty good.
author: Carlos A.

description:
Wah-sing-tung Chai Chaan Tang... haha chinese phonetics of this place... anyway....

this place is pretty legit for your HK style cafe food... prices are a tad higher than your expected HK cafe, but food is decent and place is relatively clean... relatively clean in comparison with out restaurants in chinatown... 

came here today for lunch with my friend cuz it's super hot and a nice tall glass of ice milk tea is what i'm craving for!!  I noticed that they now have  lunch specials for $6 bucks (different options for different days of the week; lunch special applies only on weekdays).  We had one of the specials, spicy meat sauce over egg noodle and we order a beef chow fun.  both dishes were decent, meaning noodles were too soggy... chow fun wasn't burnt.... it's not bad.  Us girls couldn't finish it, but the portions are decent.  it's a place i frequent when craving HK cafe style food...
author: Kelly H.

description:
I go here whenever i'm in chinatown and want good chinese comfort food. the food is average, but i give it 4 stars it's always filling and comforting. They also have clean bathrooms. you can see the kitchen, and it's clean. the floor and tables sparkle cleanly. did i mention how CLEAN this place looks? 

the baked goods are also really good. a little pricey for chinatown, but i'm glad to pay because it's CLEAN. really, it's not that expensive.

My chinese sucks, but the wait staff is always patient with me. and speaks english well too.
author: Vicky L.

description:
We have made this our eating destination while visiting Chinatown, ever since we discovered it about 5 years ago.This weekend was no exception. 

Their pastries are great and their foor is AWESOME. Some of the best if not the best Chinese food we have ever had! Seriously good...Fresh vegetables, tender beef, perfect noodles! 

Some of the dishes we had tried are their beef and broccoli, their udon soup, egg drop soup, their chow mein, their chicken fried rice, and their oloong tea. 

All orders are cooked to order and you can actually see them cooking your food in woks from the dining area. 

Their service can be slow at times, but overall not too bad. 

This time around we also tried their Taro boba drink which was great. 

They don't have people outside trying to get you in or handing out dinner pamphlets as other restaurants in Chinatown tend to do to bring in the tourist crowds. So for that reason dinning here seems to be more of a locals eatery as we have never seen any "tourist groups" dining here. 

Can't wait to return.
author: Saul A.

description: I spent pretty much whole day in SF downtown.  Then went to chinatown for late afternoon tea.  I ordered a wonton with bf brisket yellow noodle soup, hot salty lemon drink, my wife ordered a egg tart and hong kong style milk tea, $15.50, not bad for energy recharge.  At least I hit the restaura before regular dinning hour ;-)
author: Bernard H.

description:
It's almost always (depends on what hour and day you're in Chinatown) crowded here.
In the actual restaurant itself I order the baked seafood fried rice. The portion is huuuuuuuuuge and it takes longer to cook since it's baked, but it's worth the wait. The gravy is perfect, and this is coming from a girl that hates fried rice.

Before you leave, you MUST order from their Delimanjoo cart. The little custard filled treats sold there go fast - especially when they're fresh so scoop up a dozen or two while you can! You have to beat all the Chinese soccer moms to it though. But fear not, have a strong elbow and you can do it. Beware of eating it when you get it fresh though, the custard inside is HOT and it will burn your tongue.. But then it hurts so good because that dam little golden custard thing is so awesome.
author: Susy C.

description:
So I grew up in the suburbs of Chicago, where my family went to Chinatown once a month or so. Grew up eating Chinese bakery products. Then I moved to Rhode Island, where there are many 15 Chinese people total. So when I visited San Fran, I had to get as much Chinese food as possible, which included Chinese bakery items.

Are the BBQ pork buns, egg custard tarts, or coconut buns exceptional? No, not really. Are they tasty, fresh, and inexpensive? Definitely. Did it satisfy my craving for char siu bao? You bet your ass it did.
author: Jason W.

description:
i've only heard good things about this place, and the bf and i were hungry for some chinese food. we decided to get the beef chow fun, the chinese broccoli with sauce and some kind of pork chop in tomato sauce.

the chow fun was actually really good. and i thought initially it was because i gave up eating out for lent, and so any chinese food would taste awesome at this point, but the bf reassured me that it was actually really good. the chinese broccoli was good (but it's not difficult to make), and the pork chop was quite interesting. it's like a bed of rice, fried pork chops laid on the rice, and then a thick layer of tomato sauce on top of that, and then the whole concoction baked in the oven. it was delicious and the whole meal was satisfying.

they automatically gave us hot tea, which i liked. and they came in these metal beer mug looking things that was hollow, so it didn't burn your hands, but kept the tea warm.

i would definitely go here again.
author: Becky K.

description:
If it wasn't for the horrible service I received today, my overall experience at this restaurant is not bad.

As for the atmosphere, it's a pretty decent and clean place to eat.  Their bathroom is a lot cleaner than some other chinese restaurants I have been to around chinatown.  For some saucy food, I think their dishes are pretty delicious.  Their portions are reasonably decent, and the flavors in their dishes are amazing.  I always have to have the hong kong style beef chow fun when I go.  It's really saucy and has a lot of beef in the dish.

I am giving this place two stars is because of their service.  Like Leena N. mentioned, their waitresses have a hard time understanding English and after pointing to the menu of what I wanted, they still got my order wrong.  Secondly, the brought me a bowl of rice with my meal, assuming that this was part of my meal, I ate the rice as well.  However, when I got my bill, they added an additional $1.25 for every bowl of rice.  Lastly, when I asked for a take out box, the waitress kind of threw the box at me...probably because I complained about the charging for the bowl of rice when I didn't even ask for rice...

I would like to add one more thing, they offer a validation for parking, something about making it $3 for all day.  However, it is not the parking lot right next to them, but it is the parking lot near some international building on Clay street.  I have no idea if this is even true or if the waitress just didn't want to validate my parking ticket, but I thought it would be good information to pass on.

Since I did not want to leave on a sour note, I do like their bakery.  I think the dishes they offer and sweets in their bakery are all delicious and I would go back for the food, but I could care less for their service.
author: Sherene L.

description:
Skip the pastries.  

Eat the food.  There's a huge variety and it's all priced reasonably well.  This is a chinese restaurant where you'll actually see elderly chinese people enjoying the food.  Now that's a good sign.
author: Vio H.

description:
The dishes we had for lunch here were acceptable but unremarkable, except for the wonton noodle soup which was so bland that we didn't eat it. 

I would eat there again if this was the only Chinese place in town. But, geez, they need to try a little harder in Chinatown.
author: Todd H.

description:
My parents and I went here for a breather after walking through most of Chinatown. And to hydrate ourselves. My parents had Hong Kong milk tea, while I had the Pineapple & Mango iced drink. Or it is probably better to call it a smoothie, even though the menu did not list it as a "smoothie." My mother and I split a piece of chocolate cake with walnuts. Pretty good and is in par with VIP Bakery on Broadway. 

A good place that I will go to, especially if VIP Bakery is packed.  Or to kill some time, if waiting till the perfect moment to pay the parking fare at the Portsmouth Square Garage.
author: Samson W.

description:
*Review of their baked goods only.

I came in at 6PM on a Thursday looking for a mango cake for my mom's birthday.  Turns out they often sell out early, because all that was left was a mixed fruit sponge cake, topped with a variety of both fresh and canned fruits.  And since it was late and I was sort of desperate and too lazy to walk any farther, that's what I got, a small at $15.  

The verdict?  Definitely not amazing, but not horrible either:  pretty much your typical Chinese cake.   

AA Bakery on Stockton has a larger selection, much prettier cakes, and plenty of mango cakes, even just before closing.
author: Joanne G.

description:
I realize my earlier review of this place was harsh.  Now that I've come a second time and actually dined here (instead of coming in and then feeling the need to walk out), I am updating my review.

The service, though not what I'd call great, was better.  Maybe it's because of the crowd since the Chinatown Mid-Autumn street fair was taking place at the time of visit.  The menu was impressive in that it had the standard Chinese goodies (soup noodles, porridge, etc.) as well items that makes this an HK-style Western restaurant (i.e. pasta).  My dining companion and I, we ordered one pasta item and one chow mein.  Both, we would say, were decent to good.

What we both enjoyed more so were the drink selection.  I ordered a fruit drink that was a mix of coconut, pineapple, and one other (I forgot what), something which I haven't seen at other restaurant.  It was great, worth the slightly high price for a drink like that.  My companion, who's a big fan of HK-style milk tea, she chose a coffee mix drink of some type and enjoyed it also.

I definitely now wouldn't mind giving them more chance for my patronage, especially during evenings when I choose to come out to Chinatown in the evening for a massage on Jackson Street the next block over.
author: H K.

description:
Came here chiefly for the egg custard tarts, which were good, though I think I prefer the ones at Wing Lee on Clement street. I also got a coconut bun which has the sweet surprise of a mound of coconut inside. 

This spot has a massive selection of pastries ranging from strawberry cake to red bean pastries. They also have bubble tea, though I didn't try it. 

Very well-priced.
author: Miriam W.

description: One of my comfort places when I'm tired, sick, sad or homesick. (I also come here when I'm happy, haha.) Love the daily specials, the congee, and the "yin yerng" drink -- half coffee and half tea.
author: Cher C.

description:
Where else can an early bird get her 1000 year old duck egg and pork congee with Chinese donuts on the side and a Hong Kong style coffee for $4.50?

This is some thick, globby, real broken rice congee flavored with pork broth. It's a hearty bowl with a side of sliced Chinese donuts (you tiao).

I love the ambiance and the clatter of ceramic tableware.
author: May T.

description: A typical Hong Kong lounge with contemporary items like baked pork chop with rice, beef tongue with rice, iced horlick, etc.  Food here is tasty yet greasy.  Stay away from the portuguese baked rice as the yellow sauce lacks taste and the rice feels very heavy.  Extremely close to the parking lot combined with good prices so expect busy weekends.
author: Ronald L.

description:
During a business trip and in need of an early breakfast nearby SF Financial District Hilton, ABC is not open until 8am. So, the group went to WA instead. 

Good service for the C-town service. 
Inexpensive 
Taste is ok.
author: Flora C.

description:
I've only tried their baked goods and not their food. 

But walking around, the food people had on their tables looked tasty. 

Tried this hot dog wrapped pastry and this other one stuffed with taro and a few others. 

All of it was great. They were out of egg custards when we were there. But next time I'm in the city I will be coming back here for sure.
author: Eric H.

description:
According to the boyfriend who was born and raised in Hong Kong, this is one of the best "Hong Kong-Style Western Cuisine" as you can get in SF. 

As an American, Chinese restaurants can be a little scary. When I go out to eat I expect waiters to be nice to me, the counters and floors to be clean, and the menu to be appetizing. Those terribly lighted, bad resolution photos that are lamented to the menus do not appeal to me at all. But... I'm getting over my cultural naivety and realizing that even though the photos look terrible, the staff is typically rude, and the places could use a visit from Mr. Clean, a lot of these Chinese restaurants are REALLY REALLY GOOD. 

I was pleasantly surprised at Washington Bakery & Restaurant. This place is cleaner than average, and the waitress actually smiled and laughed. We ordered the abalone and chicken congee, which had a really rich flavor to the broth and the abalone wasn't leathery, best congee I've had to date. We also ordered the salt and pepper quail. The quail was fresh, never frozen (you can tell because the bones turn dark when frozen and these were gleamingly white) and the meat was juicy, the skin was CRISPY, and there was soooo much flavor. A few days later and these are still on my mind. Oh- and a huge drinks menu (non alcoholic). I had the fresh strawberry juice. Fresh and not too sweet and obviously freshly blended. 

We didn't try the pastries but they all looked delicious. I have to say this is one of the better Chinese restaurants I've been to. I'll definitely be back with a bigger appetite so I can try more next time. And the salt and pepper quail will definitely be ordered!
author: Ali R.

description:
rude! Well everytime I say that when I eat in Chinatown area, people always say it's Chinatown.
But still I don't think they deserve more than one star
author: fenny g.

description: Read someone on the Internet that this place had really good congee or jook. I gave it a try and nope, not even close to being good. I would say it's slightly below average. No taste. I know... It's jook so why would there be taste. Not true. I've been to many places where the jook has taste and I never add any kind of condiments. One example is the little place on Noriega.
author: Gir G.

description:
*This rating is solely for the odd fries -- PLEASE NOTE that  the Chinese food is awesome*

Umm...so I did it....I tried the "American" french fries! Bad bad bad bad idea! The fries LOOKED like fries you'd find at a good ol' burger joint, but it tasted NOTHING like fries! It was strange, and even stranger than the odd tasting fries were the thick blood splattered ketchup. Why was the ketchup lumpy? Why was the ketchup a deep maroon color? Why did the fries taste like animal lard? Where did they get this stuff from?

So many questions, but really it was my own fault for letting my co-worker order such a thing at a Chinese restaurant.
author: Judy H.

description: Lady waitress used the restroom and didn't wash her hands!  Food was pretty good though....
author: Nina C.

description: Simply horrible. When you expect a tip shouldn't there be service. All I ask is to get a cup of tea included in the order. Is that so hard?!
author: Nit C.

description:
I made the mistake of eating in once and I saw cockroaches scurrying across the booth.  Food was ok.  Chinese diner.  Don't eat in if you can't stomach the dirty tables and dine in area. 

Pastries are good.  I did notice that they shrank the size of their cakes.
author: Wendy H.

description:
I came here for lunch with my parents.  The place was really packed because of the Moon Festival.  We had to wait about 15 min before getting seated.  There is a nice bakery near the door, so customers can purchase Asian pastries, too.

After 10 minutes at looking at the menu, I noticed the servers weren't really coming to our table.  We had to flag one of the down.  We ordered a wonton noodle soup, chow mein, and braised beef with noodles.  All the food tasted great.

The service isn't the best here, but you can't really expect much from a place like this.
author: Rita V.

description:
Family came here to eat lunch. We each ordered a dish. Everyone's food came out except for mine. When we asked, we were told it's on the way. Thirty more minutes pass, family is done with their food and my plate still hasn't arrived. So I ask the waitress to to cancel my order. She glares at us and says it can't be done. We tell her to cancel it because it's obviously still not ready and I'm fed up of waiting. She yells at us in Cantonese and some minutes later my crappy plate of cold chicken with ginger and rice come out. 

We left a $2 tip for the crappy service. The waitress then chased after us demanding more tips. My hubby gave her an additional quarter. Will never come back here.
author: liz s.

description: I don't go to Chinatown often, but when I do, I only go to Washinton Bakery. The food is great and the place is clean. It may be a little more pricey for Chinatown, but it is well worth it. You get good food and it's clean. I like their wonton noodle soup, salt and pepper chicken wings, and their beef fried rice. Also their tapoica drinks are great too. They also serve pork buns. I ordered a cake before and it is not too sweet and the cake is very soft. If you go to Chinatown, you must come here.
author: Rose L.

description: This place is not bad. If you want a quick lunch this is the place to go. But because of it's location, the place is always pack during lunch time. The food is kinda expensive compare to the other HK style cafe.
author: Ma H.

description: Tried this spot out on a whim.  Three of us went and we all enjoyed our lunches.  I had chicken chow fun with black bean sauce, my two companions had shrimp & tomato noodles.  Mine was fine, if a bit bland.  I NEVER add soy sauce to my meals, but, I did add a few drops which improved it, the hot chili and garlic added more.  The portion size was quite large.  I tasted the shrimp & tomato noodles, found it sweet.  My companion from Taiwan said this was sypical Hong Kong style cafe food and it was spot on.  On the way out we picked up curry beef buns for breakfast the next day, these were quite yummy, I must say.  Leftovers were, as well.  I added soy/vinegar/hotsauce to it and scarfed it up.  Would I come here again?  Yes, plenty of interesting things on the menu, including salt and pepper squid begging me to come and try it.  I will stop in one morning for breakfast treats for the office and we'll see what the consensus is.
author: Donna H.

description:
This is mainly with reference to their drinks and baked goods.  We didn't eat at the restaurant, so I can't comment on their food.

The baked buns we bought were literally 2/3 empty of filling.  The egg custard tarts and custard buns were "Meh."

If you are looking for baked goods though, do yourself a favor and go a few streets over to the Golden Gate Bakery.
author: E C.

description:
Although I've visited San Francisco a zillion times, I attacked this recent trip with the zeal of a camera carrying track suit sneaker wearing tourist(minus the zero fashion sense).

On a Sunday morning I headed for Chinatown - I walked the streets, snapped a few pics and talked to the locals. Feeling hungry, I found this bakery & restaurant thru a guide which praised the food and environment but not the service.  The guide(which will go unnamed) pretty much said that the staff were not too nice and in so many words suggested that it would be better to have take out - I kid you not! Boy, am I glad I ignored that advice. My experience? The staff were friendly(granted... they didn't hold a big conversation with me/kissed my ass), polite and fast. 

The environment was clean, well lit and busy with families and friends. The pastry(strawberry with custard) was good. I think favorite part of the meal was my red bean milk drink(very yummy) and the bitter melon with eggs(an acquired taste..had bitter melon a lot as a child). I think this place will become a favorite place to eat at whenever I'm in San Francisco again. (Note: Be sure to try their  beverage list and let me know which is your favorite?)
author: CarrotBreath ..

description: Shredded duck porridge. Comfort. Always a good spot for good noms. Chinese sausage with Bok Choy rules for this Bok Gwai.
author: André C.

description: The waitress cheated on us!!! At beginning, we just wanna order couple buns and a milk tea, and later my gf wanna get the rice noodle as we'll. so we ordered all of them. For the whole time, the waitress didn't give us the menu at all, and didn't mention there's a special for morning breakfast. When we checked out, I thought its a bit pricy for eating here, and asked how she counted the money, she said that's right, nothing wrong. But when we leaving, we saw the menu says if we order rice noodle and milktea should be free. Which she over charged us 2 milk tea, 5.50 before tax and tips. And when I asked her why she didn't give us the special , she said you have to mention when you order, if you don't, then they will just charge regularly. WTF! You didn't even give me the menu, and how on earth I know it's a special!!! And she just have us 1 milktea which is 3 dollar back. I don't care that much he money, but the way how you do your business. It's terrible, and I'm absolutely not coming back
author: Kevin W.

description:
Anything that's a diner and is Chinese food is awesome possum with me. 

TAKE-AWAYS:
- This is one of the cleaner sit-in diners in Chinatown; the decor almost looks Japanese. 
- Servings are filling and they definitely pack in the rice. 
- The bakery is "cheap" but the buns in general are smaller; the egg-custards are also 5 cents more expensive than the average street price I've seen on Stockton.
author: Abel L.

description:
I have to say....this is my favorite place in Chinatown. Nothing fancy here...just your standard HK sytle foods. The service is friendly and efficient compared to most Chinatown joints. Foods however, are simply outstanding. From congee to noodles to rice dishes...it's hard to go wrong here. My fav...the black pepper beef spaghetti (do check out the pic).

As for the bakery part...they produce some of the lightest fluffiest and most delightful cakes. We just celebrated a a birthday in the office yesterday...and everyone were so thankful that the birthday girl picked a Washington Bakery Cake.
author: Agus S.

description:
I'm really not a fan of Hong Kong style restaurants/cafes.  The thought of XO sauce beef tail or shrimp wonton noodles or jook just make my stomach duck and cover.  (And that's not because I'm vegetarian, either-- I went to many a HK style cafe back in the day before I gave up meat.)  For the record, though, there is so little on the menu that doesn't have some kind of meat or sea food.  The waitress recommended I have plain jook (rice porridge).  Oh yes-- that's always appealing.

Everyone here was Chinese save for one white lady, who no doubt came because her dining companion was a Chinese gent.  The service is abrupt, I guess if you can squeak out some Chinese (Cantonese preferred) that'd be helpful.  Or you could resort to pointing to menu items.  The black tea (Lipton?) comes in really cute tin cups, I must say, and the portions are pretty fair.  $6.25 for wonton noodle soup.  $6.25 for some kind of beef tendon noodle soup, too.  A lot of noodle and rice dishes... but again, very few that do not include meat (you can, however, ask to have the meat omitted).

The baked goods at the front counter look nice, but I'm not sure how they taste-- probably mediocre, I imagine, as would fit the restaurant appeal and appearance overall.  Forgive me for sounding very un-PC, but unless you grew up in Chinatown or a similar neighborhood-- or are straight from the old country-- then I don't see how you'd find yourself wandering in here for a bite.
author: Lynn O.

description:
Not bad Chinatown! Not bad at all. The first thing that caught my eye was that this place was clean..and most importantly .. they accept credit cards! Wow! Finding a place in Chinatown that accepts plastic is about as rare as finding a fat waitress at Hooters! 

We walked in, and were immediately seated. the place and menus were clean, and not sticky. Some old school dives that I've been to had menus more sticky than your dad's porn mags.

Had the beef brisket noodles, and the wife had the han and macaroni soup. Also tried the cold Ovaltine..yummy! Everything seems to be under 10 bucks, and there are many drinks and desserts to choose from as well. the beef is okay, average...typical,,,.nothing to jump for joy. So, nothing screams to me that this place is special...but it certainly isn't a bad place to visit if you happen to be in C Town.
author: Jerry C.

description: Congee is decent but the decor is a departure from the traditional Hong Kong bakery and congee restaurants.
author: Alfred L.

description:
Zero Star.
I do not appreciate pube hair in my food. Thank you.
Well, at least they didn't try to deny there was a piece of (pube) hair, unlike ABC. However, at ABC, it was hair from the head. This one was from god-knows-where. I am not that picky with my food, but this was my bottomline.
author: Wanda K.

description: I still love coming all the way to Chinatown just to grab a bite here. Orea milkshake, wings and something else from their variety of choices. I always leave happy.
author: A W.

description:
Mmmm...there's something so comforting about having jook, fried dough, and a big mug of warm soy milk on a Sunday morning.  I also like their beef chowfun and wonton soup.  This place is in the heart of Chinatown but it's surprisingly clean and their servers actually smile once in a while.  They serve all kinds of soups and noodle dishes that are all worth trying.  The table next to us had some fried chicken wings that will make me go back for lunch.

On your way out, don't forget to pick up some pork buns or some other yummy pastry for the bus ride home.  Most are only $1 each.
author: Nina L.

description:
The service here is what you would expect from a typical chinese restaurant, pretty bad.  The menu option includes a pseudo/messed up version of western foods.  I am not a fan of Hong Kong food, where they destroy traditional balances western food.  I like Eastern food and I like Western food.  However, I do not enjoy unbalanced version of pseudo Eastern or Western food.  However, that doesn't affect my ratings, since I understand that people might actually enjoy the different twist to traditional dishes.  

Therefore, they get 3 stars.  The service isn't good and the food is better than ABC food.  Just another average place.  I wouldn't make a special trip here.
author: Maria S.

description:
i recently decided to find the best baked pork chop hk style rice dish.  this place came in pretty high for me.  in fact probably the best in sf chinatown.   ABC in san mateo has the best overall.

their pork bun, pineapple buns are expensive and not so fresh as ABC on jackson which makes them every hour or something.  

a cheap and filling hk style lunch.
author: Kevin L.

description:
This place is more COMFORT food than GOOD food, in my opinion.

Front is a bakery, back is a restaurant. Fast paced environment- has that 'sit, eat, pay, go" feel to it, though there are some seniors sitting around sipping coffee and tea, reading newspapers. 

The waitresses are pretty much all middle aged mothers (in full hair perm and acrylic nails, might I add) who seat and serve you really quick, but hospitality is definitely not in their top priority. 

If you speak Chinese, it's always a plus, because they got a little impatient with me and my bf when we were trying to order something new on the menu. 

We had the ja lerng (fried bread wrapped in haw fun, topped with sesame seeds and hoisin sauce with soysauce) and a baked seafood with creme sauce. Both were okay and filling, but definitely not a 'omg i'm craving Washington's ______ right now" status.
author: Ann L.

description: I'm writing this review since i doubt i remembered to from before.I have gone here several times...throughout the yrs....last time i was here was days before chinese new yrs 2012... I enjoy their wet saucy beef chow fun. I rarely go to sf anymore, but when i do...we usually eat here. The workers are friendly. They loved waving and complimenting  my baby girl. It was her first time there. But i enjoy eating their food and drinking hot horlick mmmm
author: linda y.

description: all i have to say is... get the salt and pepper chicken wings. SO GOOD! and also i would have to say it is one of, if not the, cleanest restaurant in chinatown. must try place in your visit
author: Michael L.

description:
This is probably one of my favorite tea houses in San Francisco. I ate here often when I lived up there and whenever I was in the city. They get pretty packed and busy but I feel they are worth the wait. 

We usually get hong kong style chow fun, seafood yee mein (or any yee mein is good), fried chow mein, fried chicken wings, ice lemon tea, and their beef congee with a raw egg. (wo dan ngow yuk jok) * I really recommend their congee.However, the only thing I don't recommend is their yow ja gua (fried bread sticks), sorry bad english translation! But  they are always cold! Other than that, I really do like most of their food. Give it a try when you're in town!
author: Karen L.

description: Very typical Cantonese place. It was good for my group after a long day in Napa and the desire for some comfort food. I had the wonton mein and the chicken claypot rice. Just very cheap comfort food.
author: Jamie T.

description:
Like an ideal one night stand: 

Clean, nice, large and tasty with a huge variety of possibilities.
Doesn't mind if you just want a quickie or if you want to take things slow for awhile. 
Cheap desserts on the way out! 
And although you might remember it, it certainly won't remember you.

Score!
author: Charles T.

description: Their baked pork chop rice is the best.  I have yet to find a better baked pork chop rice than theirs and I have searched near and far.  Their milk tea and papaya milk are very good as well.
author: Emily C.

description:
Love this place!  After calling several places in Chinatown looking for Salt & Pepper Chix wings, Yelp pointed me in the direction of Washington Bakery & Restaurant.  The lady who took my order was super nice and friendly, which is not always the case when I call chinatown because I do not speak cantonese (yet - totally on my bucket list)!  :(  I told her I needed 5 orders by 2pm (giving approx 1 hr).  I got a little lost on the way (my fault) and called  to ask for directions.  The lady was super sweet again and did not get frustrated with me.  I came in (10 min early) so she rang me up, made me an itemized reciept by hand with no protest, and 3 really nice ladies kept checking on me and smiling really big.  Lol...  I was suprised how cheap they were too! $34 for 5 orders - 7 per order.  I know that most of this stuff should be a given when it comes to customer service, but I never get good service in Chinatown, so I totally just go for the food!

My food came out, piping hot, they put it in a tray for me with, then in a big carrying bag and sent me on my way.  My group love love loved the wings and I thought they were amazing as well!  They were so hot when i got back to the office (5 min walk) that they were burning my hands as I devoured them because they were just that good!!! 

I can't wait to go back to this place and try some of their other items (i took a to go menu)!
author: Brandy B.

description:
It's one place I've found in California that actually makes pineapple buns the way I like them. I don't know what it is that makes them different at other places, but I also love that they have the mini size for a perfect snack.

Food itself is ok, I've only tried a fried noodle dish once and I probably wouldn't get it again. The service is friendly enough though the server insists on speaking to me in Cantonese even though I consistently respond in English. Doesn't really matter because I understand her but I think it would be odd to assume that I do.
author: Amy C.

description:
I came here on my first photowalk... where I met Tinna, Victor, Berna, Phil, Angelo and so many other great people.  

On our way from Grace Cathedral and The Fairmont, we walked down through China Town and stopped here to starved off our hunger and quenched our thirst.

There were so many decisions to be made, that I choose not to make any.  I had a pearl milk tea, a ham & cheese pastry, another ham & cheese pastry and 2 donuts.  Yes, I shared.  But not all of it!  It's mine, all mine!  I don't regret a single bite... it was all soooo good!

I am very grateful to be introduced to you all that day and for you to introduce me to this great spot!
author: Lauren C.

description:
As a frequent tourist in this great city, I make it a point to stop here every time I'm in town.  The food is what you can expect of Cantonese soul food.  There's something about this place that is very inviting to me.

I had a pleasant experience recently.  I've been hearing my dad talk about  Clay pot rice for years and we haven't been able to  find this dish anywhere.  (Anyone reading this who knows of another place that serves this, please let me know.)    Anyway, we were able to find it here. We were both very excited to order it and it was extremely fun to watch him transform back to his childhood days. It didn't really taste like anything super special to me, but he (normally very difficult to please) loved it and vouched for it's authenticity.  

Another plus is that it's close to parking, although they don't validate.  I also agree with a previous post about a dislike of their mugs.
author: Jone H.

description:
Energizing. Jovial. Ample.

Not a fan of greasy, MSG saturated Chinese food, I was skeptical of this "bakery" that served Chinese fare, but I was pleasantly satisfied with the flavorful congee and the (greasy, but not nauseatingly so) Yee Mien.

The chicken in the congee is tender;  the abalone: processed.  The Yee Mien, a new dish to my culinary vocabulary, was a delicious surprise - similar to a savory, saucy chow mien, but with more bite and less grease.

The place has a nostalgically positive energy and the servers are always busy but attentive and happy.  As an additional plus, you can shun mothers words and grab dessert at the bakery BEFORE you eat...AND after!  The jelly roll bread is the fluffiest!

Prices average $6-14 for lunch.

Know Before You Go:
1. Careful of the hot tea they serve in metal barrel cups!  The cup is cold to the touch, but remains SCALDING hot throughout your entire meal!
2. Parking nearly impossible in Chinatown.
author: Jane L.

description: Food is oily and tasteless.  Price is 25% more expensive than nearby restaurants that serve better food.
author: Byron L.

description:
Ervinna: Dinner tonight?
Choon: Only if it is cheap.
Ervinna: $15/per person max. How does that sound?
Choon: ok, I am in.

http://www.todayslunchdeals.com/san-francisco-ca/deal/details/38

That was all it took to convince my friend to go dinner with hubby and I. It was a gorgeous day. The weather was sunny and breezy. I just want to hang out and stay out with friend and hubby. Since we have been spending quite a bit and have a few big trips coming up, we decided to find some cheap and good restaurant to enjoy the night. A friend told me about a great wan ton noodle place in Chinatown. If this place did not come recommended, I would not have walk in with a place with rows of pastry in front of the store. It just does not seem like the type of place you would go for noodle because it does not look like their "specialty" is noodle. 

We ordered wan ton noodle ($6.25 each bowl), we had free-range chicken with wanton, roast duck with wan ton. It is probably of the best wan ton I have eaten in United States. It is close to the one you get in Hong Kong. The won ton is medium size with good flavor. We bought some pastry to go as desert and breakfast. The price is very affordable, $1.2 for 3 mini pineapple bun. Good deal.
author: Ervinna L.

description: cheap breakfast. nothing special but you can def get your congee/chinese donut on and be on your way quickly.
author: Misha T.

description:
The first time I was here, I gave this place a 4 star and its been about a year now since I came back and it's actually not that great.

The delicious chicken wings that I came for the first place was very, very, disappointing.  I barely ate one wing.  I took my significant other there and he was sicken by it which makes me look bad!  I mean the wings did not taste the same at all.  For some reason the wings are more fried this time around and it just taste like there is a ton of oil on it.  Seems like they are trying hard too hard to copy the Korean Bon Chon wings which I think, was a big mistake.  Heck, leave it to them to make the Bon Chon wings and leave yours alone!  What a mistake they did changing the wings taste.. tsk tsk.  But their mongolian beef dish was pretty good.   

Oh and the servers, kinda rude.  We sat down waiting for a while before we got the waiters attention and one even raised her voice in chinese saying something to me and she looks irritated.  Sheshh lady, I'm the hungry one and I don't speak chinese! I should be angry not you!  =)
author: Linda T.

description:
Don't even think about eating here if you are white.

I found out the hard way after having the most humiliating experience eating here tonight. I was the only white person here and the man who waited on me seemed to show an utter contempt for me for no other apparent reason. While he was extremely friendly and animated to all of the other guests, he shifted his composure completely every time he came to my table. He put on the most extreme display of rudeness I have ever encountered; he refused to look at me so much that he even turned his head away from me when talking to me, as if he were completely disgusted with me.

He seemed to become even more appalled when I asked if I could pay for my meal with a credit card, so I offered to go get cash from the ATM outside. At this point, I was already thinking that it was a bad idea to eat here and the ATM wasn't working, so I went back in to tell him that I couldn't get cash, and to just cancel my order. He huffed and made more gestures that made it apparent that he was extremely annoyed if not disgusted, but since my milk tea had already been served he reluctantly gave in to accepting my credit card.

I ate my wonton soup without ever looking up. By the time I had finished all the wontons and only broth remained, the smell was like that of a basin of water used to wash a dog. At the end of my meal, before another server was about to drop my check, she looked to him for confirmation as he was passing my table. He impatiently flicked his hand at me, as if to say, "Get this disgusting white piece of shit out of here." I tipped nearly $3 on a bill that was just over $8, hoping to make amends for my imposition, but after leaving I realized that I had done nothing wrong.

I was so caught off guard by his behavior simply because I didn't expect it. I guess since a lot of my close friends are Asian, I've become blind to the racial differences between human beings. Unfortunately there are still some, like this man, who see our differences as challenges that cannot be overcome.
author: P A U L.

description:
Look closely at the Jook you have ordered. You will see small aphids in the broth.

Unless you want bugs in your food, avoid Washington Bakery!
author: Sarah H.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE!!  

They have really great baked pork chop over rice and other HK staples.  There is a great selection of drinks: tapioca, cold ovaltine, hot coke with lemon and ginger--yum!  It's usually pretty busy around lunch and dinner but the waitstaff provides swift service but don't expect them to be particularly nice or polite.  

During Chinese New Year they serve poon-choy but I believe you have to make reservations in advance so they know to prepare it.

Their baked good selection is not bad albeit a tad expensive.  There used to be little egg puffs filled with custard goodness but the stand has since been transformed to a dim sum area and as of last week that area of the restaurant offered no specialties.

Washington Street Bakery is much better than ABC.
author: Helen B.

description:
After wandering around Chinatown looking for some friends, we finally found them here at Washington Bakery & Restaurant. My friends were having lunch and I had already ate, but of course I had to try their food cause it looked damn good. I tried some of the thick noodles and cuttlefish balls that they were eating. Both dishes were actually really tasty. The thick noodles were in a oyster/mushroom type of sauce and was very delicious, but it was sooooo oily. And the cuttlefish balls were in a curry sauce, and those were really good too.

As for me, I ordered a pineapple bun to much on for my sort of dessert that was pretty good too. Overall, the food is good, but way too oily. Also, the service is kinda shitty here, but not surprising. My friend asked for a bag for the leftovers and the lady was yelling at him that she didnt want to give him a bag... i dont know what her problem is, but whatever. crazy lady! haha

if im in Chinatown next time and craving some HK style food & pastries, i'll probably stop by .

note: they only accept credit/debit if your tab is over $20.00.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Call me a local, but I don't consider Chinatown the spot for good Chinese food. Dim sum to go, maybe. Sit down dining? A resounding "bu!" 

On the occasion that I do happen to be in the area, however, this is usually where I make my stop. They have all the dishes that you would want in a HK style caf, and a bakery at the front of the store (which I think is decent but nothing spectacular, especially of late).  I'm a fan of the rice dishes (personal favorite being the beef & tomato), various chow funs, and the wonton soups. 

The drink list is large and accommodates something for everyone. One warning about the red bean milk: there are a LOT of red beans. The milk is gone in two seconds so you often get stuck with a cup full of beans. Be careful not to choke when you are sucking it up through those straws.

I prefer it to ABC, but it's not the cheapest in the 'hood. Portions come aplenty so that might help you justify some of the cost. Fast & efficient service--though not the most patient if you catch them on a bad day. They take credit card too--a huge plus, if you are familiar with the "cash only" ways of Chinatown.

If you too are caught in a situation of being stuck between Stockton & Kearny, this just might be one of your better bets.
author: Rona J.

description:
I probably give this place a 3.5 instead of a 4.0. However, I lean closer to a 4.0 than a 3.5. 

Food: I've had multiple items here. My favorite is the crispy noodle w/chicken. I love the sauce and they give me ample portions that I never finish. I always take the other half and it acts as my dinner for the night. I also love their milk tea. They make a pretty decent milk tea and it's not filled with ice. Pretty good taste even when I ask them to lessen the sugar. I've yet to try their roasted duck noodles, but judging from friends, it seems to be a top item here. Their cakes are pretty good too (4 stars here) and they are reasonably priced. I like their chocolate cakes! Not as sweet as some of the Western bakeries and it tasted pretty fresh.

Customer Service: I would give it 3 stars. They are pretty quick, but I've def. been to friendly places. I have no issues with this place though. They get the job done and aren't rude. 

Ambiance: This is probably one of the most spacious Cantonese style cafes in Chinatown. It's pretty clean too. + 1 point for cleanliness and room space.

Location: It's pretty close to Portsmouth Square. Easy to find location off of Washington Street. Convenient and located between multiple bus stops.

Parking: Portsmouth Garage is the closest one (less than 1 block). You can also park at the Park & Ride off of Battery St. for $3 bucks on the weekend (highly recommended for the entire day! and you can catch a shuttle to Chinatown for free from the parking lot. Shuttles from this lot runs every 15 minutes). Street parking is available, but meters are pretty pricey and it's hard to get a spot during peak hours. Also, the meter maid is pretty rough around these parts. They WILL ticket you!

Price: A bit higher than some of the Chinatown cafes in the neighborhood, but the portions are pretty ample. 

I would recommend this place for lunch and snacking. I also love their cakes.
author: Tina C.

description: It's HK comfort food ... dumplings, stir fry ho-fun, jok and my favorite - beef tendon.  Also bake rice dishes.  It's close to the parking garage and it's good comfort food.
author: CAScuba Y.

description:
Let me get this out of the way: my obsession with this place borderlines on the unhealthy. 

This is true because I make it a point to eat here during our annual trip into San Francisco. This is true because the last time I was in the city, three separate parties brought me here three separate occasions. This is also true because of one very special server who made our stay very awesome and had great things to say about life and living and working - we later deducted that he was the owner or part stakeholder, judging by his demeanor and hospitality. This is true because every single time we come it's packed to the brim with no signs of letting up.  Certainly this speaks volumes about the quality of their food, service, and decor right?

Not exactly. Yet I lust (yes, lust) for their CURRY FISHBALLS, Singaporean style noodles, fried HK dough in a crazy Cantonese peanut butter/hoisin sauce, wannabe-American-yet-truly-HK rice and spaghetti cream sauce porkchops, and assorted soupy noodles and wontons. Everything is too oily and too delicious. 

Decor is generic Asian, with simple chairs and tables and ultra illuminating florescent light. Service is abruptly brisk and Chinatown efficient. 

It's a sentimental thing really; I only patron Washington Bakery on vacation and with my best friends.  Also the food takes me back to a HK style childhood I never had. My 4 stars can be attributed mainly to those reasons. Your mileage may vary but judging by other ratings, I strongly stand by this place. 

PS funny story: Last week I hit this place up and brought some outside food that I wanted bagged when I finished my meal. I asked the lady at the pastry counter for a plastic bag and she started bitching that the food was not even from their store and how they could tell by the packaging. My friends were offended I guess, but even as she was yelling at me she was reaching for a bag to give me. Note to self: Actions speak louder than words, especially in Cantonese :]
author: Gary H.

description:
