One of cleaner-looking HK cafes in Chinatown, just a notch better than D&A and ABC (and in return not as cheap), along the lines of VIP cafe. A typical HK menu. They make fresh egg puffs with custard inside, kinda like fresh-made twinkies. Overall, this is one of my favorites.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
**Review for breakfast bakery items only**

Oh wow to the Curry Chicken Bun!!  How can they make a bun flaky?  I'm sooo amazed!  It's like the bun-pie hybrid.  For $1.25, it's a steal!

Also, the deep fried curry beef bun, put in the toaster oven, it's crunchy!  :D

Their tiger skin roll is also mighty delicious.  Interestingly it's denser than the regular cake roll.  It is kinda pricey $2.00.  Yeah.. it's only $2.00 but for chinese bakery, that's kinda expensive but highly worth it.
author: Gigi T.

description: Sam Wo was closed, so I went over to this place! n guess what, they served congee with lots of varieties as well!!! I ate the pork with preserved eggs, that was very tasty, and what a big bowl! I should have shared with people, may be 3 or 4, and order other stuffs which looked very tasty too. I would definitely come back here again for congee!
author: Nat N.

description:
For what its worth, five stars. 

I repeat, this is good 'ole standard HK style cafe food...it's not gourmet and it sure as hell ain't 5 star service, but it's always reliable, and relatively quick for the amount of people that come in and out of here.  If you are a regular, they are pretty nice and know you when you come in, but otherwise they aren't too bitchy at all either...I mean, like I always say, standard Chinese service.  Whatever... 

I love the seafood baked rice and their "luo mi fan" or sticky rice is the BEST.  I also like the iced lemon tea and the "yin yang" isn't bad either.  Although sometimes if you get the boba in your drink its kinda soggy and not cooked through...either way, I'd go with the more "traditional" drinks .... i forgot to mention they also have a kick ass "hong dou bing" aka red bean milk drink thingy... hey, I suck at translating all these things, aite! DONT HATE! (i still rock :D hehehe)

And, what the hell are those delimanjoo thingys?!  Are they supposed to be a copycat version of the "gai dan zai" the REAL egg puffs?  Sorry to those who like those thingiemabobbers, but I HATE them, blerhghhh!! Egg puffs are NOT supposed have custard in them, but maybe I'm just an ABCFOB that doesn't know what I'm talking about. No to delimanjoos!

Then again, I like Washington, and I always will! :D RWWWWWAAAR!
author: Linda C.

description:
SF Food Inspection Score: 3 stars

Their buns make me happy...
author: Kristina C.

description: We've had the salt and pepper chicken wings, beef and egg rice, noodle soup, and my kid's favorite- spam w/macaroni noodles.  Everything tasted fine.  We ordered buns from the bakery for breakfast since we didn't have any tasty options at our hotel.  I like the fact the ham and egg buns actually have a fried egg in it versus the yellow egg rectangle you normally see everywhere else.  Yummy!  Drinks are good too.  Clean restaurant earns them an extra star.
author: Corrine C.

description: My mother likes to eat here often and when I'm in Chinatown with her, I could careless where we eat. One of the factors that are important in picking a restaurant in chinatown is: IS IT CLEAN? And yes, this restaurant is clean. The food's pretty good and I often like to order the beef broccoli with rice.
author: Lily W.

description: food is pretty decent.  we got the congee and bao zi fan but too greasy.  a nice cantonese eatery.
author: Momo K.

description:
OH MY GOD!!!!! Their baked Black Peppered Chicken Steak w/rice plate is the best I've ever had in the world!

My best friend and I have been going at least several times a month for the past two-three months and every time I go, I always order the same thing: baked black peppered chicken steak w/rice and iced lemon tea.

If I were on death row and was asked what I wanted as my last meal on earth, I'd ask for that! Haha.....it is freakin delicious!
author: V M.

description: Decent taste and price. Not much selection and very small place to mingle with neighboring restaurant crowd.
author: Aung W.

description: So maybe I'm biased because I came here for noodle soup a mere 2 days after overpaying for nasty Hapa Ramen, but this place hit the spot for a Chinese noodle soup craving.  I had the beef trip noodle soup (not on the menu) and an iced milk tea - both delicious.  There is no ambience because hey - it's a cafe in Chinatown - but that's to be expected.  Especially when the noodle soup was only $5.75 (vs. $9 at Hapa for a smaller portion).
author: B. Y.

description:
This is my ALL TIME favorite restaurant in chinatown!! Back in my teeny bopper days I would go there all the time with my friends, during Saturdays, after chinese school. Now, I would beg my boyfriend to take me here every once in a while. He hates going to chinatown and I do too but  washington bakery is worth the trip. I've never tried their bakery goods but their food is scrumptious. They put ABC to shame!!

My usual is their iced lemon tea (dong ling cha), salt and pepper chicken wings, eggplant with fish sauce clay pot, beef with vegetable chow fun, baked pork chop over spaghetti, and pork with preserved egg porridge! haha sometimes more, never less!! My boyfriend gets really embarrassed when I go over board ordering food. We always have left over, which by the way, makes the perfect fourth meal (siew yea). 

For the amount of food you get is well worth its bill. All of that is never more than 45 dollars. How awesome is that? I LOVE this place. Its a good thing that the restaurant in is Chinatown, because I almost never go to that district but when I'm there, Washington Bakery is a royal treat for my tummy.
author: Jenny K.

description: I come here to get the sponge cakes for $ .80.  They're the fluffiest!  I've eaten here a few times, but I definitely come back for the pastries.
author: Linda P.

description:
This place is good for quick good Hong Kong style food on the fly.   One of my favorite dishes is their Hot & Sour Won Ton Soup.  A combination of my favorite two soups, for people that loves those two soups, then this soup is for you. Most of noodle dishes is pretty good like their Beef Chow Fun and their Singaporean Rice Noodles.  Though the pork chops are hard as hell to eat.    

Their bakery is pretty good.  Nice cocktail buns and egg tarts. Oh they also have a versions of the eggettes.  But it okay because they might always make it fresh and they tend to be sitting there for a while. So if you want to have it fresh. Ask them nicely to make it.

Good price for decent food.
author: Chris C.

description:
Hate to knock on everyone's 4+ star rating but I beg to differ.

Summer of 1996, my momma bought this mocha coffee roll from Washington Bakery for breakfast.  It was shared amongst my brother and I.  I ate 2 slices, my brother 3.  It was the summer time so with no summer school, we were chilling at home.

An hour or two later, my brother and I start feeling nauseous and sick.  We vomited.  And vomited.  And vomited.  And I'll never forget that hard squeezing in my stomach when I vomit because it was f**kin' painful.  My worried mum took us to the doctor's office and guess what?  We had food poisoning.  

After vomiting all day, I finally feel a bit better at night.  I clearly remember watching the gymnastics portion (my favorite!)  of '96 Olympics on TV while hugging my poor poor stomach.  And I'm thinking, I'm never ever going to eat anything from Washington Bakery.

Perhaps things have changed, but after a food poisoning experience, I don't think anyone wants to go back!
author: Michelle W.

description: I came here for a quick grub.  I ordered a lunch special curry chicken over rice with lemon ice tea. The ice tea was not bad, but the curry chicken was a major disappointment.  First of all, the meat has no flavor at all, it's almost like chewing at a bland piece of white meat; second, the curry was very water down.  I had to spice it up with lots of chili sauce and pepper.  This place does have fast service and affordable pricing, but still a far cry from ABC, and I am not even a fan of ABC.
author: Jamie L.

description: Hong Kong style fast food featuring the staples like noodles, jook, baked rice and wontons. Pretty comparable to ABC bakery with its offerings. Come here during the happy hour specials where you can steal a great deal. Variety is good but most of the food is 50% pre-made to boost service speed so there's a little sacrifice in quality and favors. Things that usually take long like beef tendons are pretty tough to eat and not cooked long enough. Service, though, is great here; the waitresses are vey caring and almost motherly in nature.
author: Ed L.

description:
Pretty darn good!!!!
Went here for lunch today.
The service is quite good (friendly in a non chinese way).
Had the:  "Deep Fried Chicken Wings to Spicy Salt " ( it was very good!)  and the   "Beef Stew Won Ton Noodle " (tasty without a lot of heavy oil or fat taste.
I will return another day!!!!!!!!!
author: tiny w.

description:
My all time favorite HK style restaurant by far compared to any other place in the bay area. I am not a big fan of their bakery goods but I do like the ham and egg bun and the egg custards is decent. They do have a lot of choices to choose from but in general I don't like to eat buns. I love their curry chicken w/rice, scramble egg and shrimp over noodle, sticky fried rice (forgot the exact name), wonton noodle soup (their wonton is so good), salt and pepper chicken wings are the best and the list can go on. Their curry fishball is really good too, the fishball has a nice texture. It isn't soft and soggy. 

Their fruit drinks are all made with real fruit even taro and avocado is made with the real stuff. No powder for their fruit drinks so they are good. Best place in chinatown, it's the cleanest you can find but the price can be a step up from the other's in chinatown.
author: Flora W.

description:
3.25 stars.

Came here once for lunch and other times for their bakery and coffee. They have a pretty huge selection of pastries and bread, and their prices were decent. But for the lunch plates, I thought it was on the expensive side considering it is in Chinatown. Although this is 3.25 stars, I need to qualify it, because relatively speaking, I have the impression and experience that Chinatown restaurants aren't that good to begin with. 

Would I come back here again? Not on my own volition. But if a friend or group wants to eat here, I wouldn't mind.
author: Sam W.

description: Really excellent authentic Chinese food here.  The portions are hearty and the prices are within reason.  So much good food I don't know where to start.  I tasted a few of my party's items and all were yummy.  I think I found a new favourite Chinatown SF eatery.  Leave it to my sister's friends to find a good place to eat.  Try the lemon coke...it's heavenly.
author: Amy J.

description:
God damn. After running off for lunch with my friend so he could bitch about his family situtation, we scrambled to find a lunch place in the 12:30 hour. Two Viet places were packed out, and it's raining, so it's not like its a leisurely joint through chinatown to pick up some dim sum to go is an option. 
soo...enter Washington Bakery. I've been here before, and the service was just as i remembered it. SLOW AS FUCK. whatever, i waited for my noodles and made notes on the food landing on other people's tables. the place is clean now, and the food is good. i'll always be down for more. I'll try the bakery stuff one day, but so far, four stars for the restauraunt. (should really be 3.5, but shit, it's friday, and i'm feeling kind)
author: Jessica S.

description:
I've only checked out the bakery part.  It's really hard *not* to stop and drool over the little cakes in the case.  I love love love the lemon cake here, and the little sour gummy lemon slice they put atop it just makes me swoon with its kawaii-appeal.  We bought a few cakes to go, and once my dad fell asleep, mom and I snuck into the cake box and ate his share.  The next night, we bought more cakes and did the same thing.  Let them eat cake?  No no no, let *us* eat *your* cake!  The moral of the story is that the cakes from Washington Bakery are loverly, or that you can't trust women.  Take your pick.  Their BBQ buns and tuna buns were pretty tasty, too.

They also make the most adorable animal pastries, like gold fish, that are about five bucks.  It would make a nice surprise gift for someone.  HINT HINT.
author: maiko h.

description:
OK food...  can't complain, cant rave about it either.

Good place to satisfy a Hong Kong type Chinese food craving.
author: Stanley L.

description: AMAZING. My mouth is still scorched from the porridge, fried bread, and salt/pepper wings. Extra points - tea in a metal mug.
author: Kevin L.

description:
I went there a couple weeks ago on my weekend trip to SF with a friend.  We wanted Congee for breakfast on Sunday and looked up Yelp reviews for recommendations.  We found Washington Bakery and it didn't disappoint.  The food was good.  We got chicken congee and pork with preserved vegetable congee.  Both were tasty, but I preferred the pork with preserved vegetable over the chicken congee.  

The service was... well, shall we say, interesting... They were definitely not the friendliest bunch, but I suppose that was part of the overall experience.
author: Karen W.

description: San Francisco Chinatown, you gotta know where to go and what their specials are....this place.....they have a great ginger scallion pig intestine dish, verry  verry goood....
author: Leslie Y.

description:
Washington Bakery is a go-to spot for a good friend of mine.  It's a typical Cantonese cafe in terms of its offerings.  I believe it's one of the best in Chinatown.  They serve good meals and have a huge selection of baked snack.  

My friend and I came here for an afternoon snack.  It's a perfect place for afternoon tea.  Whether you're looking for a full meal, warm soup, or just bakery snacks, you won't go wrong coming here.  

We shared a pan fried flat noodle dish (guotiao/he fen/ho-fen/ho-fun, etc.) with beef, hot and sour soup, and each had the Cantonese-style milk tea.  The beef was tender, noodles flavorful, and the soup was a little on the salty side, but also flavorful.  That soup came in a big ol' bowl.  We were both able to get 3 bowls each.  It was probably meant for a party of 4.  This is what I love about Chinese restaurants... big bowls of soup.  Not this dinky 2-sip crap you get at Western restaurants... but I digress.  

The egg custards here are pretty good, and often sellout by the afternoon - get there before 2ish and you should be fine.  It's definitely on my short list of places to get egg custards in SF!
author: Leo C.

description:
Came here again yesterday somewhat unwillingly. But to my surprise, their YEE MEEN (noodles) were really good! It had just the right amount of moistness and just the right amount of sauce. Plain and simple. 

However, their LOR MAI FAN (sticky rice) was not so good. It was bland and not chewy or soft enough. And as usual, its supposed to have LOP YOOK (some kind of semi-dried/preserved pork I believe). But 90% of the lop yook was lop yook FAT (supposed to be half half). So I definitely passed on that, cause I go for the ALL SLIM. And I've had their cheesecake here before. Chinese cheesecake just doesn't compare to the more American/Italian bakeries. And although I knew better, I did decide to try their blueberry cheesecake here. It was lacking moistness and close to being dry even. And I'm more used to having blueberry swirl versus four blueberries (if they were even real and fresh) placed near the bottom of the cheesecake. Hm.... not good. But it is better than frozen cheesecake! Perhaps I am too much of a cheesecake lover, therefore leading my expectations to be too high. 

I was told that they have killer pineapple egg custard buns here though. Will try, will try.
author: Elaine H.

description:
Just went back to Washington Bakery & Restaurant, after not visiting in over half a year (due to living farther away from Chinatown...). Still really enjoy this place and its simplicity; the desserts still look so tasty, and the meals/entrees are still great values. Big portions for less than $10!

Looking at the menu itself is overwhelming...way too many choices, and they all sound so good. Chinese, other Asian, and American dishes mixed in; they serve Pad Thai, udon, etc. as well! Strange....I was tempted to try those dishes, but opted for "Fried Fish Cake with Salted Fish Rice Noodle" this time. Really good; fried and unhealthy, yes, but I loved the texture of the fish cake and the little bits of Salted Fish. Mmm! Homecooking the way I like it. =)

P.S. I wonder why I haven't tried any of their desserts yet......I was watching a couple of ladies dive into their large slices of cake yesterday and felt my mouth watering, literally.
author: Helene K.

description: I can only comment on the bakery and drinks. I got BBQ pork buns and watermelon boba. The BBQ pork buns were on the small side for the price ($1), both in terms of filling and bun size. I'm used to bigger ones with more meat for $.65 in LA Chinatown. It was good but not filling. I really liked the watermelon boba, though. They use fresh fruit when a lot of others use powder, so A+ for that. The boba was the perfect texture. It could have used more ice, maybe, but otherwise it was really good.
author: Liza D.

description:
On the North side of Portsmouth Square.
All kinds of yummy goodness. I'm a fan of crispy noodles with the sauce poured over them so they get kind of soft but yet still crispy...hmmmm.

Baked treats at the front - good coconut buns, these little fresh egg custardy madeleine type cakes and the more exotic-to- the-white-girl offerings like drypork salad buns, lotus seed cakes, and preserved egg cakes.  It's nice for me that the signs are bilingual.

Good smiley service though not as quick as Golden Star Vietnamese around the corner.  Plenty of space -  all kinds of congee, baked rice, clay pot, noodles.  

Not the cheapest place in Chinatown. It's about $7 for a plate of chow mein, but its a huge dish.  The salt & pepper squid are excessively salty to me. 

The atmosphere is table-service cafeteria - kinda like the one place I ever ate at in HongKong, but without the clouds of cigarette smoke and Bladerunner lighting.

I brought back some baked goods for my predominantly Asian team (mostly Hong Kong & Taiwan) and they all love it so I'll let that speak for itself. 

My Pinoy in-laws would probably love to stop here for a quick, cheap, and substantial post -Mass lunch.  

Overall - a good place for a weekday lunch.
author: Robyn C.

description:
Good Reliable Hong Kong Style Food.  Their baked goods are delicious also.  They basically have everything from Jook to Won-ton Noodles to Baked Pork Chop over Rice, to your normal Chow Fun.  

Favorites: 
Shrimp & Egg over Chow Fun,
Preserved Vege & Beef with Chow Fun
Bacon, Egg white & Dried Scallop Fried Rice

HK Style Tea and Iced Lemon Tea (HK style) are good as well.
author: Bessie T.

description:
Part of my regular breakfast rotation...You can get all sorts of crazy HK-styled baked or fried buns, none of which cost more than $1.10, such as:
Curry beef bun (baked)
Curry beef bun (fried), which is like a jelly doughnut but instead of jelly there's curried ground beef inside!
Ham & Egg bun: a bun sliced open and stuffed with an over-hard egg and a slice of ham
Cocktail bun: a sweet bun with some icing and coconut.
Supplemented by coffee and a banana, this may beat out a bong rip and a cold pizza crust as the breakfast of champions!


And for lunch, you can't go wrong with any of their chow fun applications.
author: Suo L.

description:
My bf took me here, he says it's good. I ordered a sandwich so I wouldn't know. But it's his friends. :] He knows too many people. Sorry to say. I think it's alright, better then ABC. Clean and a really WEIRD experience...
when I took a bite out of my food, my boyfriend and some guy would be talking. Every bite. awkward turtle.. hope he doesn't real this! haha. but thats when we were first going out. got used to it now..
author: Carolyn Y.

description:
Food: 4 stars
Service: 3.5 stars
Value: 4 stars

I used to come here everytime I went to China Town. But this was the first time in more than a year and it didn't disappint me. The place is now cleaner than before (except the restroom) and like other new cafes and restaurants, they put a big TV on the wall for customers to watch news and programs. 

We came here for snack and ordered a mango with grapefruit juice for dessert, a hot ginger honey drink, and a french toast. Everything tasted pretty good and the price was cheap. The waitress was friendly and attentive. Good job!
author: F T.

description:
Haven't stepped foot in this place for MANY years. 
Not sure if the restaurant has changed hands... but I thought I'd share with you guys my experience at this place.  When it first opened, I came here quite often, given that their food were pretty good!
However, one time I came here with my mom and ordered the XO beef chow fun.  Boy was it good until we see a big fat cockroach inside.  Well we notified the waitress. and she said just said "oh" and took our plate of noodles away.  

No apologies.  Didn't cook us a new one.  Still charged us.  
I understand Chinatown is a dirty place, and that cockroaches back then were quite inevitable.  If she could've handled it better, I'd probably still be going there every now and then. 

But for now, NO THANKS even if they offer me a free meal.
author: Emily L.

description:
Baked rice dishes are GREAT!  
I haven't tried a better tasting baked pork chop rice dish with tomato sauce in the area.  For $8 bucks you get 2 great pieces of pork chop and rice.  Good portion of both (not too much rice b/c they give you too little pork chop).

Their bakery item, only tried the sugar donut, wasn't that good.
author: Lillian M.

description: I just went to the San Francisco Street Festival. It was extremely busy and crowded. I ordered the Mongolian beef over rice with hong kong milk style tea. It was pretty spicy and they have a lot of meat. I went to other restaurant and they try to cheat you. They put more green onion and red pepper. Not enough beef! The price is a little bit more expensive. Other restaurant charge between $5 to $6 for this order. This restaurant charge you $7 for this order. The food is okay but the service is terrible. Last time I came here, I stood there for more than 10 minutes before they gave me a table. I got piss off and left!
author: Allen K.

description: We picked up a few breads/pastries and small custard pies. I was disappointed with the custard because it lacked sugar. I usually don't like sweets too sweet, but this didn't really have any sugar at all. I've tasted much better elsewhere.
author: Jerod Y.

description: Good jook (minced beef).  Only okay for HK style pan-fried noodles - noodles and sauce are good, but the seafood isn't particularly plentiful and you can tell it was frozen.
author: Melinda C.

description:
This is the best Chinese fast food restaurant in Chinatown. If you beg to differ, please email and tell me where to try.  Now, this is what you shoulder order. If it's a cold day, order their bbq pork won-ton noodle soup. If there's three to four of you guys/gals, order the spicy seafood claypot, salt & pepper squid, and peasprouts with dried scallops. Good? Right? ;-)  What did I tell you, it's the best!

However, stay away from their pastry. Though, they're a bakery, their pastries aren't very good.
author: unhei k.

description:
I go here at least once a week and oftentimes stand out as the only white person there but I don't mind because the food is delicious. My favorites so far have been their great selection of soup and rice dishes. 

This place really feels like you are transported to Hong Kong and the prices are very reasonable and the service has always been quick. 

Try the BBQ Pork Bun its to die for.
author: Nerd A.

description:
Cool.  What to do after a long day spent at the free admission aquarium?  Get delicious cheap food of course!

This place is hard to find parking, so we finally decided to park at the lot half a block away.  Only 2.50 and hr, not bad.  We went in starving and tired around 4:30pm and good thing we still made it in time for their afternoon tea specials!  (til 5pm)  Only 3.80 per selection, we got almost everything.  beef noodles. won ton noodles, spicy fried fish, fried squid, HUGE fried chicken wings, fish balls on a stick, soy fried noodles, uh and something else.  What's a bonus that each one comes with a free drink/dessert!  There were 6 of us but we got 8 plates, so we each got a drink (+1.00 if cold), and 2 desserts.  Yum, the place is clean and the lady was nice.  Restroom was also acceptable, (i know, in chinatown!).  chicken wings and beef noodles very good, but don't get the fish balls on a stick- u only get 6 wrinkled ones!

They also have very nice looking bakeries and cakes, but looks a little overpriced to me.  Would go again though.
-j
author: Janice's A.

description:
Good lunch eats. Seems *cleaner* than the rest of the HK cafes in Chinatown. It's pricier than the others though and doesn't really have any specials, I think. They cater to a lot of fi-di people on lunch breaks also. 

This is where I go when I need a beef chow fun fixing. with lots and lots of hot sauce. Mmmmm...

Thank you Washington Bakery & Restaurant!!!
author: J T.

description: Amazing baked pork chops over rice
author: William C.

description: My usual plate is the baked chicken over fried rice with some kind of tomatoey sauce. I also get their salty fish and chicken (or beef) fried rice plate. If you plan on ordering anything else, I suggest you not! The wonton noodle soup is not worth it. They only give you three pieces like any other restaurants like this. If you want wontons, I suggest you go to an actual wonton restaurant. This place is only good for lunch because the dishes come out quick. I would not suggest here for dinner. Too overpriced.
author: Annie H.

description:
I'm reading the other reviews, and I'm not sure if the other reviewers actually visited other restaurants for their comparisons.

I mean, sure, this place has beautiful decor, and yes, there's the...wait...I'm not sure what else lures gullible tourists to this place.  This place is NOT authentic Chinese food; the fact that it is a bakery-turned-to-a-restaurant shows that the managers are just in it for the profits (and you can see it in the prices.)  Sure, $10 a dish is considered cheap elsewhere in San Francisco.  But honey, you in Chinatown now.  Anything over $6 is a ripoff.  Take it from someone who grew up in Chinatown all his life.

The dishes are good, but like someone once said, "MSG can make dirt taste good."  And the service is horrendous.  Here is my story that made me open my eyes: If you are a foreigner, sure. You'll get served quick, but know that you are supporting three mistresses who discriminate against their own people in order to please the tourists.  That's actually racial discrimination: when you will only serve the starving old Chinese ladies (who happen to be my grandmother and her friends) AFTER you serve the foreigners/tourists who all arrived 10 minutes after us.  We only ordered two dishes, but the other non-Asian people ordered at least 4 dishes.  We STILL got served last, while those people were already a quarter-way into all their 4+ dishes.  This is not acceptable: not of waitresses, not of decent human beings.

And again, the food.  This place looks nice and fancy, but their food--trust me: MSG all the way (I'm still thirsty 4 hours after eating there).  And this wasn't my first visit (it will be my absolute last though).  Before, the texture of the meat seemed like it was cooking in the pot since morning and OMG, the drinks are made from canned preservatives!!  I gave this place three chances, and it failed all three.  I implore you: please stay away from this place.  The ladies who run it are bad people, and beware: they include gratuity ALREADY into the bill (confirmed with college-student calculation)

If you are visiting Chinatown, please actually explore this crippling town and stray more than just a mere block away from Grant.  Grant Street has been the epitome of aggressive commercialization and the destruction of the Chinese culture.  Go to Powell, or Broadway, or maybe even the alleyways... there, the decor is nothing to brag about, but the authenticity is real and so is the love.

Enjoy your stay in Chinatown. :)
author: Alan L.

description:
Recently revamped the interior - a little cleaner and a little brighter.

I love their crispy pan fried noodles (black pepper beef is the bomb).  Their porridge is quite good too.

For the price this is definitely a good place to go.
author: J H.

description:
This review comes from two Chinese people that love good "Hong Kong-ese" comfort food!!!  This place is cleaner than most HK cafes.  Don't expect to have a quiet meal and impeccable service.  Its a little pricier than the typical HK cafe, but the food was good.  Their congee hits the spot on a cold rainy day!  We had Mongolian beef and bean sprouts and chow fun with XO sauce.  The chow fun dish was incredibly yummy!  This place serves yummy Chinese comfort food!!  

We also ordered some chinese pastries from the bakery.  We ordered a sweet sticky red bean pancake thing, and he LOVED it!  It was a little oily for my taste.  I ordered my favorite, mexican bun.  It was incredibly soft and not too sweet, just the way I like it.  I was surprised to find a sweet custard, which I usually dislike, but really enjoyed in this one.
author: Alden W.

description:
AHH! i just can't resist this place! each time i walk by, my body forces me into the door! even after a complete meal at another restaurant, my eyes light up and my tummy is suddenly hungry again! (yuck to me!) hehe. theres nothing like eating the XO beef-lo mein, while washing it down with my lemon iced tea. mMMmm...  i am hungry now =o)   

there is one particular waitor who's always nice! the other ones just do their jobs.  

i don't really care if its more expensive than other places, because i'd rather pay more and be happy with my food.  this place somewhat reminds me of Hong kong, except i in HK, i can get the same meal for like 25 cents. hehe kidding.. 

i wish they didn't take out their custard-filled egg puff machine =(. an ounce of my heart broke, when the machine broke....what a bummer!
author: J L.

description:
my second time here. the first time was better than the second time..i have to say.
i ordered "salted fish ( a bit stinky too) with minced chicken fried rice. this is one of the classic dish in H.K so i expect them to cook it well.
But i was let down. it's not as good as they make in L.A.
i was relieved! Haha
i don't like H.K style porridge but my friend insisted on ordering one so we did. 
it was not bad but i still prefer the good old traditional rice porridge which has good ratio of rice and liquid. not too thick and not to thin.
we also ordered one of the classic which is pineapple bun with butter.
OMG! it's good! esp when it's steaming hot coming out.....
but i don't think its made of pineapple or anything alike....haha
it's delish anyways.
author: Joanna H.

description: Went here with a couple of friends last weekend and we all ordered the baked pork chop over rice.  It was pretty good with its own unique flavor, a sweet tomato sauce with a hint of coconut.  The pork chop wasn't dry as some with some places.  Wasn't bad at all but not as good as VIP.  If it wasn't for a piece of hair in my friend's dish I would give this place 4 stars.  Is that what they meant by authentic HK style food?  I found hair in some of my food while visiting HK.  =)
author: Samson M.

description:
baked rice chicken with black pepper sauce. man it was good. rice was moist, chicken and sauce were good. it takes a little longer than the other dishes, but it's def worth the wait.
it's a bit big, definitely not for just one person, unless you eat quite a bit. 

but this dish for $8 was definitely worth it.

it's a smaller restaurant/bakery, that definitely feels like mom/pops. if you are in the are def give it a try. but it's not the type of restaurant to drive far for it. that's imo, since it's a smaller restaurant where you grab something and go.
author: H C.

description:
One of the cleaner places you'll find in Chinatown, however, they must not want you to stand near the bakery counter because I felt what was dripping water from the ceiling which hit me square on the noggin. I look up, lo and behold, a busted pipe fom the unit upstairs leaking into the restaurant below. Someone better call the plumber because that is a major health code violation.  

I would have given them three stars as the food was cheap, fast, and satisfying... the service was decent too. The leaking ceiling thing dropped them a couple stars.
author: S L.

description:
I have been on the hunt for Beef Tendon noodle soup.  Now for those who have had it in Hong Kong you'll know what I am seeking.  The version I got her had tendon and some beef, but the ratio of beef/tendon and noodle was off.  Too much noodle.  Maybe because it was to go affected the ratio.  $6.00 for the soup.

The way it should be is big pieces of tender beef strips and long pieces of tendon.  Sometimes they are still attached.  Can someone recommend a place?

Atleast the noodles were cooked well and the broth was flavorful.  I am sure there are other things here that they do a better job at.  I'll let you know when I try them.
author: Po L.

description: Best oreo milkshakes ever!!! Haven't had one for a while and was craving for one! From my past experiences, chinatown restaurants are dirty and what not; however, this is probably of the cleanest cafes I been to around this area. Food is good, service is great. Most definately coming back here soon. Probably during the upcoming moon festival fair. 2 thumbs up!
author: Tommy T.

description:
Just had some good Chinese (Cantonese) food.  REALLY good stuff at a reasonable price.

My wife had the Pineapple bun (attention peeps: in a Chinese bakery, pineapple buns do NOT have pineapple in it...it's just a yummy sweet bread that "looks" like a pineapple cuz of how the crust on top breaks) and pork meatball porridge.  My sis-in-law had the Baked Pork Chop with Tomato Sauce on rice and I had the BBQ Pork fried rice (not being too adventurous for first time there).  
Best dish, hands down, Sis-in-law's Pork over rice.  That thing was SOOOO stinkin' good!  Tons of good flavor and she said it's the best that she's ever had (and apparently she orders this a lot when she goes to a Chinese food place for the first time).  
Second place goes to my wife's Pineapple bun.  Even though I've had these before this one was moist and sweet and very yum-o.  
Third goes to my fried rice.  Very tasty and the rice was light and airy...not totally filling which was nice cuz I didn't feel all gross afterwards.

Go check out this place as it's easy to find as you park in the garage (on Kearny between Clay and Washington) and when you exit the elevators it's infront of you to your right.  Easy to find and SUPER good.
author: Dave K.

description: We've been here a gazillion number of times and always have food that are reliably good and service that is brisk but friendly.  With the amount of food items on their menu, it would probably take another gazillion of times for us to try them all, but what we've had so far, our favorites are the noodles wrapped on bread, the fried quail, the scrambled eggs with bitter melons and their Hong Kong milk tea.  Good food, good service, clean bathroom, what more can one ask for in a Chinatown eatery?  Yesterday, I bought some Durian buns to go.  So sublimely delicious!  Even my mom, who usually dislike the smell of the fruit in a pastry, thoroughly enjoyed her half of the bun that we shared.  The only complaint we have is their absolute refusal to sell us one of their mugs that they use which keeps the warm beverage warm without heating up the outer layer an iota.  But we are still working on that.  Meanwhile, we'll continue to familiarize ourselves with the food they have to offer.
author: Yvette F.

description:
It's take-out day.  We were in a hurry, so I told Hubs the Yelpers love this place.  We stopped by for the black bean "pai quat" pork rib rice claypot for $7.50.  It's not printed in English (Chinese on the menu), so you have to ask for it. They have about 8 rice claypot items to select from.  The 2nd item was the beef stew won ton noodle, $6.50.  Yes, I know I indicated "we were in a hurry" but funny how when Hubby wants to eat a certain item (rice claypot), we're suddenly not in a hurry anymore because it took 20 mins. to cook.  By the time we got it home, the rice was kinda dry and the meat was too.  I didn't like the couple of chunks of beef stew in my won ton noodle, it looked like old dark meat, not very flavorful & tough. The noodle was OK, but the won ton with the visibly encased shrimp was fishy smelling.  
The menu is extensive.  If you're a beverage fanatic, they have 48 cold beverage choices, 16 hot beverages & 14 pearl drinks to select from.  You could have a foodless liquid meal instead by trying a ton of these!  

The place is huge and probably gets crowded at lunch time, but for 5:15 PM on a Sunday night, there were less than 20 patrons in the restaurant. We didn't try any of the pastries but they do offer small pieces of cake about a 2x3 inch piece for only $1.25.  Enough for a taste and not too much to cause caloric damage. 
So, Yelppies, I felt let down.  Please tell me another love story because this one broke my heart, it failed to deliver.
author: Ry T.

description: If you want a fast and cheap lunch, come here.  We all ordered the shrimp dumplings with noodle soup. We also ordered the tasty salt and pepper chicken wings.  All the food was served hot and tasty. The service was wonderful. Our waitress was very pleasant and friendly especially since we had a party of 15. It's easy to find. We will come back.
author: Lori L.

description: llove this place. foods good bakery is good. super friendly waitress
author: Cindy L.

description:
ehhhhhh.

golden gate bakery was closed for vacation, so had to default to this bakery for my chinese baked goods craving.

they had all my favorites, but it did none of them justice :( my pineapple bun was too soft and chewy, and felt stale. even the crust didn't have that subtle pineapple aura that i love so much. my sponge cake tasted waaaay too eggy. if i wanted eggy, i would have ordered them scrambled.

no thanks to you bakery, i'm now 2 lbs heavier and not at all satisfied. pee-yoo!
author: Diana L.

description:
if you want the experience of a cha-chan-tang (chinese-style coffee shops) in hong kong, but don't feel like paying $1000 for a plane tix and fighting jet lag, you should check this out. hot yin-yeung (coffee+milk tea) and a plate of beef chow fun w/ gravy and i'm one happy girl. my sis actually declared that the pork chop baked rice here is *better* than the one she had a few months ago in hk. 

every time i walk in here, i feel like i'm back in the hk again. waiter kinda huffy? welcome to hk! waiter more interested in watching the street than getting your bill? welcome to hk! ok, i'm not trying to keep you away from visiting my motherland -- i'm just saying you can't let wait staff attitude get to you.  hk people just don't have time for that shit, especially not at $10 for a giant plate of food.
author: Angi C.

description: I've been here a few times and it's usually excellent, but one time it was not so good. in general, its authentic chinese/HK style food (duck jook!) and not pricey at all. I love their pea shoots, their salted chicken, jook, and fried dough. the desserts are excellent as well. it's simple inside, nothing fancy, but if you just want to eat good food in chinatown without a long wait, i recommend it.
author: Natasha F.

description: YOU HAVE GOT TO TRY THIS RESTAURANT! It's totally convenient, affordable, and DELICIOUS! I always go there and everytime I try different dishes. My favorite are the Fried crunchy noodles with Mongolian beef! Yummm! I go there all the time and always leave satisfied. You have got to try it! Also, those instant noodles that they have there are awesomeee! Usually when you cook them yourself at home they have like that MSG taste, but this place is very affordable and tastes MSG free and still good! Definitely eat at this restaurant when you're in Chinatown. It's clean too! The bakery is also good! The slices of cake is sooo yummy. Satisfies me all the time after a good meal! Check it out! You won't be disappointed.
author: Valerie T.

description: The food is decent Cantonese food, but don't buy the bakery items.  They're not fresh and old.  The egg custards are too sweet and lack the "eggy" taste; the walnut cookie is old and the walnut is rancid; the sponge cake is fluffy but lacks any taste.
author: CalBear H.

description:
-----updated on 1/10/07----
there is a afternoon tea special from 3pm to 5pm.

it is like McDonald's mini meal, so u pay less but u will get smaller quantities. I got a mini bowl of wonton soup (half of the regular bowl) and a regular cup of hot milk tea, the combination at the price of $3.80
there were 3 wonton in the soup, and it still tasted so yummy!

My sister got a mini bowl of "pork ball" porridge with a small bowl of bean curd. The bean curd is not good, so don't try it. I understand that making bean curd in the San Francisco (or even in the U.S.) costs a lot, soI didn't think it would look/taste like the ones in my village in China. 

My advice: don't expect that u will have pretty delicious bean curd (dessert) with lower prices.  Tell me when you get the origrinal (hand made)bean curd. When u eat that there, be sure to add some sugar because it tastes like nothing.

the hot milk tea and wonton noodle soup are my favorite food there.

the service was ok and the atomesphere was ok

the bad thing should be parking and the crowed counter in front of the entrance.

the price was acceptable, and i highly recommend their cakes that it is hongkongnese style.
author: Sue S.

description: One of the best spots in SF for authentic Cantonese style lunch dishes. They have the best Hong Kong style pan fried noodles! Their wonton noodles, rice porridge (jook), chow fun and rice dishes are all good as well. They probably make one of the better Ying Yang fried rice dish - an awesome combo of a tomato based sauce and an egg white creme sauce over shrimp and scallop fried rice.
author: Roger Y.

description: I eat at Washington's when i am busy on week days...when i don't have time to wait and they make it pretty fast and delicious. so i think it's a pretty good deal. It's a clean chinese restaurant. most of the times the tasty chinese food end up in not-so-clean places. if u go early morning or in weekends, u'll get a variety of chinese bakery too! prices are very reasonable and their service is not so bad most of the times.
author: Sarah O.

description: Food is always great here. The congee is delicious, the chow fun, chow mein and hong kong style lemon ice tea never disappoints. Price is also not bad. I haven't tried the baked goods yet, but I will next time i go back.
author: Peter T.

description: This time I came here solely for their bakery because I was on my way to the airport and want to bring some pineapple bun back home.  They are cheaper than your normal bakery of Shengkee etc, but their quality isn't the best.  I had 3 small pineapple bun for $1.75 and half loaf of toast was also around that range whereas other places is around $3.  I used to come here for lunch, but that was too long ago for me to really critique right now.  But overall, their wasn't many selection in the bakery when I went and that was probably because it was Saturday evening.  But it'll do.
author: Crystal L.

description:
Four stars just because there is some sort of gravitational pull I feel to this place.  Maybe its all the MSG.  Also, they are nice about letting me bring my own tea without giving me the "You pretentious little bastard" look.  (For a tea person...I have experienced that WAY too much!  And in San Francisco, of all places).
  Their food is decent and I recommend their special treats.  My personal favorite is the gravid smelt.  Nowhere in this city can you get so many egg-filled fish for so cheap.  And their light, fluffy texture with a satisfying level of spice is equally rare of this particular dish.
  Their larger dishes tend to be on the heavy side so be prepared to get full or die in the process (again, I blame the MSG).  I recommend their noodle dishes over their rice dishes, and their jok is quite tasty (though Yee's on Grant is a bit better).  And as for their hot pot dishes, they have always kept me interested.
  A definite Hong Kong cafe amidst the many different options San Francisco's Chinatown has to offer.  Since they have managed to keep their allure and charm, as well as their tasty food, I must rate them rather high ^_^
author: Scott N.

description: The food here was great! Service was a little hard to track down, but the food was amazing!
author: Anthony H.

description: Really pretty disappointing.  Now, I must admit I'm not a connoisseur of authentic Chinese food but I do love most asian food.  My co-worker took a group of us here the other day for lunch.  He is chinese and thinks the food is great so who knows.  I thought the sauce was pretty bland and the meat was not particularly tender or flavorful.  I had the house special chow mein.  Service was ok but not great.  All in all, I've been worse places but I'm not going to be rushing back here anytime soon.
author: Laura B.

description: I come here to eat a lot when I'm in Chinatown.  I don't think I've had any of their baked goods in years, but I eat lunch here.  They've got HK-style food, which I like.  I'm only in Chinatown on weekends so the wait is usually killer.  If you come a little before the lunch crowd, you should be fine.  I admit, it is NOT the cleanest restaurant and I avoid going to the restroom here, but I like the food.  I almost always order the baked porkchop over rice with tomato sauce.  Yum!
author: Kris L.

description:
if you can help it, don't take your food to go because if you stay and eat you can enjoy the bright, clean ambiance of a chinatown cafe.  with a good mixed of the young and the old, washington bakery is too cute to pass up for afternoon lemon ice tea drinks on a hot SF day.

but if you take it to go - here comes the 3 star rating - the food is not that good.  the seafood noodles tasted like it was boiled in fish sauce. yuck.

this place is sorta near my office (kinda?? not really... 4 blocks away??) so i come here sometimes and dont have time to sit and eat.. but if u do have the time, definitely opt for that option.. its a difference between 3 and 4 stars.
author: Tina L.

description: We used to come here all the time when I was little! Stopped by in the morning for a quick breakfast with my brother before an appointment downtown. 4.50 for a breakfast meal with macaroni, ham, sunny side up egg, and 2 pieces of toast. And your choice of coffee or tea. Let me forewarn you that the bowl of macaroni is dinky. It comes in a rice bowl. SO SMALL!! Compared to other HK cafes in Oakland Chinatown, the macaroni is weak. The piece of ham is gigantic and a bit salty. I asked to exchange the grape jelly with the strawberry and the employee got a bit pissy with me and threw the strawberry jam package in my direction. The service was kind of lacking even though the place wasn't busy at all. I guess the waitresses were all running up and down bringing the baked goods upstairs. Anyway it was a trip to be back here and I suppose if I was in Chinatown and needed a cha chaan teng fix I would come here.
author: Lydia W.

description:
This is the only place i go to in chinatoawn. The place is cleaner than most places and the food is great. My favorites are the salt and pepper chicken wings and the duck and wonton noodle soup. ITS THE BEST. The selections of buns are great also in addition of tasting great. 
IMO the best place in chinatown to eat
author: chris h.

description: I come here for traditional Hong Kong cafe food - porridge, chow fun, wonton noodle, etc.  Good location (up the street from the Portsmouth garage), clean for a chinatown eatery with chinese clientele instead of tourists.  Baked goods are not the best, but decent.
author: Rob C.

description: I used to come here a lot when I was in middle school, but not as often now.  I like their macroni with ham. They have this little shop that makes these egg puff things in the front, but I am not sure if they still have it anymore, but those were pretty good.
author: Janet Z.

description: Came in here a few times to pick up paper wrapped sponge cake and raisin buns and they are pretty good. Decently priced and they open until about 10pm.
author: Yan M.

description: This is a great bakery in Chinatown.  The people behind the counter are very friendly, and it's a nice place within walking distance of the financial district if you want to grab a quick snack.
author: Jon N.

description: salt and pepper pork, that's what's up!!!! and also this chinese breakfast dish that i can't quite pronounce or even begin to spell out for that matter. this is a solid alternative to not waiting in a mad line for R&G. but maybe 2 bucks more than it should be per plate. still, worth checkin' out for a quick meal. the macaroni isn't good though. either is the beef tongue curry.
author: Michael A.

description: for a restaurant in chinatown, this place is really clean. during the 45 minutes i spent here on a wed morning, i think they must have polished the front windows and doors twice! i had the duck wonton noodle soup which was quite tasty with little if any msg. the duck was too fatty for my liking, but the wontons and noodles were perfect. grabbed a couple of creme tarteletts on the way out. these were disappointing and tasted too much like lard and artificial flavorings. go for a simple lunch of snack, it's a fairly casual place that serves the standard cantonese style dishes, noodle soups, rice plates, porridges, some dim sum....plus a variety of chinese bakery items.
author: helen l.

description:
this place has very poor service.  the waitress left our table after 30 seconds of impatience because we didn't order fast enough.  we had to repeat our order to another waitress.  

the bakery is pretty pathetic.  the worker there lies in your face that these are freshly baked... so then how come after you order them she goes to put them in a microwave before serving it to you?

if ever goign to chill here, just get a drink and avoid the bakery. 

didn't get a chance to look too closely at the menu, but everythign there seems like 50%-100% more expensive than it should be

milk tea was ok. 
pearls were good.
red bean looked good.
drinks are 3.50... really overpriced, but might be good
taro drinks made from powder
avocado drinks made from 'flesh' (probably fresh) avocado.
author: A M.

description:
I ordered bokchoy on the side with my wonton noodle boiled chicken soup.  The soup came with veggies inside, the waitress should have told me so i didnt' have to order that dish of bokchoy.  I'm eating alone.

Anyhow, the noodle was adente, as they say it.  The wontons hold together nicely, and the chicken was fresh and firm with the skin so nice.

At $7.50 its not exactly a cheap eat for a single dish.  There's alot of carbs in that with all them noodle.

Large, clean, and busy atmosphere with tables full of patrons.

$7.50 soup
$6 veggie
$4 tip
author: Kevin T.

description: Authentic Cantonese lunch joint with a decent bakery. Great place to grab lunch. The portions are huge and the food is fast and fresh. Their egg tarts and paper-wrapped cakes are great.
author: Peter S.

description: The food was tasty. We ordered this tofu dish, and this other veggie dish for a late night dinner. The workers were friendly, and the place can get filled up. I would definitely come back here to try the cakes.
author: christy w.

description: I went here for a hong kong style lunch with my family and found it to be enjoyable. We ordered the baked pork chop in tomato sauce, mongolian beef, and noodle soup - they were all pretty good. Does get a bit packed on the weekends, though. A good rec for cheap chinese food.
author: William T.

description: For chinatown, its descent. The bakery is better than the food.....quality wise.
author: Warren D.

description:
I tried their Pork and Thousand Year Old Egg Congee and got a pretty big bowl for $5.  

I also tried the Cocktail Buns.  They were not great, but better than the ones I found from some other places.  It seems to be very hard to find good Cocktail Buns in general.
author: E H.

description:
i love anything mini so got superexcited about the mini pineapple buns (3 for $1.10 or $.45 each). plus i got to rationalize to myself i could grab food here and still hit up some other places.

the pineapple buns at Super Napoleon were better but maybe it had something to do with the compact size. who knows...
author: Princess Pompom Patootie W.

description: Always good food and more or less good service.  The chicken with the won ton and noodles is the best!
author: Em K.

description: The food here is decent for their price because its cheap and fast. Their chow fun is pretty good and their pastries are decent, but their service isnt that great. If you want to get a quick bite for lunch, this is a good place to go.
author: Q W.

description:
The service is horrible. When I walked in to be seated, I did not even get a "Hello how many?" or even a simple "Hi". Instead, they were just standing around doing nothing while one person had brought me to a table. These fobs also do not know how to listen. My brother asked for a COLD milk tea, and they gave him a hot milk tea. I guess they don't speak engrish well. The noodles were mediocre, and the smell in there is horrid. The only good thing in there is the pineapple bun with coconut filling. And when I asked them to LI LI LI LI LI LI LICK MY LOLLIPOP, they didn't know if I was speaking English or Chinese.

Cliffnotes:
The service sucks.
Don't know how to speak english.
Pineapple bun good.
author: weezy b.

description: I'll definitely come back again. They have a good selection of baked items, meal items, as well as hot and cold drinks. I've only ordered pastries each time I've been here (note: I've got the biggest sweet tooth of anyone I know!). However, I always take a bite out of others' dishes. Hence, I can tell you that my fiance's wonton noodle soup was hot, steamy, and they did not skimp on the wontons! My sister's Cha Siu Bao (bbq pork bun) was nice and fluffy on the outside, and filled with a lot of very tasty pork on the inside. Her boyfriend's Hong Kong Style Lo Mein was also very good. On my second visit, I had their Coconut Cream Puff, a bite of my friend's Blueberry Cheesecake (she loved it!), and my other friend's Lemon Cake. We were all very happy with our orders. My only complaint: seems like they were out of several items fairly early in the day. Their display case didn't seem to have as much selection as the first time. Can you believe they were out of egg tarts by 1 or 2 in the afternoon?? In any case, you should still give it a try!
author: Lucy H.

description: This place is pretty good I guess.  It's not too far from work, but sometimes there are a lot of people at lunch time, so it's better to go later around like 1ish.  Lot of variety, but I usually get one of the fried rice places, fish porridge, or something simple.  The ja lerng seems to always be stale when you order it at lunch, at least the two or three times I ordered it at lunch.  Probably leftover from the morning.  Never tried their pastries, but they look pretty standard for what you find at a bakery anyhow.
author: kenny w.

description:
This is a restaurant I can go everyday if I am working in San Francisco.  It is a Hong Kang style restaurant.  

They provides a lot of varieties.  I ordered the fried rice with backed filet of garoupa and BOBA milk tea.






I
author: Dylan W.

description: I use to always come to place for dinner with my friends three years ago . I used to like this place because it's the cleanest cafe in Chinatown . But now that I'm older and wiser, I don't like this place anymore . Their food is overpriced esp. the rice and noodle dishes . You can get cheaper and better at a lot of places in Chinatown . The things on the menu bore me . The Mongolian beef here is good but too salty . The tomato beef with spaghetti wasn't really that good .. it was very bland and the pieces of beef were too big . The mixed fruit split tasted weird but the banana split is good . The iced longoon drink is good - not too sweet but just right . The tapioca drinks here are either hit or miss . The tangerine with pearl is super duper sour so I suggest you stay away from that unless you're pregnant lol . The honeydew with pearl and watermelon with pearl is good though because they use real fruits and its kind of creamy in a way . Their buns they sell here are good .. very fresh but their cakes aren't really that good . This place is sometimes really crowded and the service is okay but be sure to give them good tip or they will ask you to give more on the way out lol . How rude huh ? But another reason why I used to love this place is because I used to love the little cakes with the cream filling  called Deli Manjoo (Yes, I looked up the name for all of you) they use to sell in the corner .. but they don't sell it anymore ! I am so mad !! lol they were my favorite !!  They should bring it back ! ):
author: Eileen L.

description: Having never eaten in the restaurant section of Washington Bakery, let me endorse the bakery of this establishment with a big "woo hoo!"  This place is absolutely fabulous!  As much as I really like Eastern Bakery in Chinatown, I would select Washington Bakery hands down--any day, any way.  Their egg custard tarts are killer.  All of their deserts are amazing--and they aren't the kind that look like they are going to be really yummy but end up leaving your taste buds disappointed, lonely, and sad.  So no worries.  Pick up whatever looks tempting with confidence.  Don't neglect to get extra goodies for coffee in the morning.  One other thing that makes this bakery better than Eastern are the fruit drinks they make.  Oh . . . my god.  Lovin' it!  I mean, how can you not love a fresh fruit drink that you can walk around and sip and then chew the tapioca pearls as you slurp them up with a big straw? Maybe it's an acquired taste, but try it.  You might just shout "Yes, yes, yes!"  as much as I do.
author: Shadi G.

description: this is the only place i go to eat in chinatown. why? b/c it taste good and the place is clean compared to all those other restaurants in chinatown...they have a large selection of bread and drinks...my fav food is the chicken wings, friend tofu, and fried calamari.....noodle soup, and fried rice...is also great! they are the most busy during lunch. whoever goes to chinatown should check out this place
author: Karen H.

description: Good for lunch near the FiDi. Mid-range price for a Chinese lunch - but it has a sense of authenticity to Hong Kong. Personally cantonese isn't my favorite genre of Chinese, but it does the trick for me at lunch. Personally enjoyed the roast pork wonton noodle soup & the he fun (broad noodles). Portions are large (perhaps not for the wonton noodle soup), so we shared 2 dishes between three people. Not a bad deal...
author: Jeannette L.

description: ive been here a few times.  cheap and convenient eat.  i always just get a drink, soup, and the something melon with dragon noodles.  i forgot what the exact name of it is on the menu.  but its basically silver noodles or bean thread or clear noodles with tzit gua or that furry melon thing.  from what i can tell they dont put msg in their food which is a plus.  the soup is always a bit too watery for my taste.  not enough stuff in it.  always makes me more thirsty.  the noodle dish they give a huge serving of and i always have enough for another meal the next day.  service is pretty fast.
author: claudia y.

description: Nice place if you are looking for variety:  HK-style plates and drinks, soup noodles, porridge, baked goods.  The only items not available are BBQ and dim sum.  Waitresses will rush you to finish your meal when there's a line at the door.
author: Fai C.

description:
this place suckksss!! i hate it. our order toke an hour. we asked about our order many times... but they ignored us. when we got really pissed. my cousin yelled at our waiter.. she just told us that our food was coming. when we were getting up to leave... our food came. but we still left. 

dont go to this place. service sucks
author: Sandy W.

description: This Chinese restaurant stands out from the rest.  Though the selection is pretty much the same as any other Chinese restaurant, the quality to me, is better than the rest.  Big thumbs up for having the rare deep fried bread sticks for eating with "jook" with noodles wrapped around.  I have no idea what that is called but I LOOOVE it--soo good with the sweet soy sauce they use for "churng fun".  And yes, it's true, it's mostly always crowded here.
author: deeks ..

description: i frequented this place literally for 8 years and those ppl in there all know me.  I go there for lunch, my fav is the pork chop rice, the 4 treasure rice, shrimp and egg chow fun, and won ton noodles.  Those are my go to.  I find their lai cha to be exceptionally yummy too.  of all the places ive been to, i feel that they are one of the better ones.  i go there once a week wihtout fail!  love this place!!!
author: mooncake w.

description: I don't like MSG. Every time I eat here, I get extremely thirsty. I ordered some chow fun and egg whites with scallop fried rice. It tasted pretty good due to the MSG.
author: bob k.

description: We tried the value for money afternoon tea set which comes with a hot drink and item of your choice from the Tea set menu. Top-up if you like a cold drink. It cost $4.75 before tax. We ordered 3 different sets; the century egg porridge, fried chicken wing and Curry fishball. It is just like those you get in HK. The porridge was tasty but not as smooth. Curry fishball was not very spicy. I like the yummy fried chicken wing which is so far better than those other HK cafe I have tried in USA. Overall for that price, it is good value and close to what you get in HK. I hope to come back to try other dishes.
author: S H.

description: this places gets a very low rating from the SF dept of health - 62 -- that is about as low as they go -- here is the latest rating -- http://dph-extranet2.sfdph.org:7777/pls/eeop_htmldb/f?p=132:2:3500150978975688::NO::P2_LOCATIONID:3816
author: M B.

description: food was good - the wontons in the wonton soup noodle was tasty, the beef in the beef stew noodle soup was tender and flavorful...the crueller wrapped in the rice roll was a bit bland..and the plate of chinese broccoli was really oily...but it's cheap:D
author: Michelle H.
